name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@clusterslugs @JohnCantrell97 With 128 bits of entropy, you can definitely recover a private key from pubkey with 2^128 operations, so on average 2^127.

With 256 bits of entropy, you need on average ~2^128 operations, but possibly more, and with vanishingly small probability many more.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@JohnCantrell97 That all sounds right to me. I think it can be summarized as:
* Less than 128 bits of entropy is definitely worse than 128 bits.
* More than 128 bits of entropy may be somewhat better than 128 bits, but not much.
* More than 256 bits of entropy does not help.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @baltakatei The statement "all looked-at coins are heads" is equivalent to "each coin individually is either ignored or heads".

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: The explanation is, I think, that Poisson distributions have relative high variance, even as N grows. In addition, using it in an exponent turns this variance into a mean change. Even if the coins looked at were symmetric around N, the average of 2^(-N +- a) is not 2^-N.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: This result was very surprising to me. It is equivalent in probability to always just checking ~72.1% of N, for any N. I would have expected that this probability would tend to be close to 2^-N as N grows at least.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Alternatively, the probability that a coin is "accepted" (ignored, or heads) is (1-1/(2*K)). All coins need to be accepted, so our probability is (1-1/(2*K))^(N*K). The limit for K=infinity of this is also exp(-N/2).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The correct answer was 2. exp(-N/2) = 2^(-N/log(4)) = 2^(-0.721*N).

The number of coins is binomially distributed with n=NK p=1/K, which for large K is a Poisson(N) distribution. E[2^-X] for X Poisson(N) is this value.

The answers are formulated as negative powers of 2, because probability 2^-X is the probability you expect from (always) checking X coins.

So the question is: this strategy of checking coins independently is equivalent to checking N-0.693 coins, N*0.721 coins, or N^0.577 coins?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Toss K*N fair coins. Look at each independently with probability 1/K, so on average you look at N coins. What is the probability that all the coins you look at are heads, as K grows to infinity?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @brilliancebtc @fiatjaf @rot13maxi @mempool @WhenTaproot Another complexity is that when tweaking/adding keys, and treating the output as x-only key for BIP340, you need to remember which contributions to that key were negated and not, because while the signing itself corrects for it, tweaking doesn't (A+B is not the same as -A+B).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @brilliancebtc @fiatjaf @rot13maxi @mempool @WhenTaproot One complexity is when trying to verify tweaks in a batch-verification compatible way, you need to reveal whether or not the sign of the output was changed. That's why BIP341 script path spends include negation bit in the control block.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @brilliancebtc @fiatjaf @rot13maxi @mempool @WhenTaproot There are certainly complexities introduced by x-only keys, some of which we didn't properly anticipate when designing it, but this is not it - tweaking always results in a valid x-only public key again.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @brilliancebtc @fiatjaf @rot13maxi @mempool @WhenTaproot The sign correction happens inside the BIP340 signing algorithm. Private keys d and -d have the same corresponding x-only public key P, and thus also produce the same signature when signing a message m.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @barackomaba You're right, though a nit: it *is* how much theoretical work that block would have taken to produce. A lower hash value does not mean the block required more work, as every hash below the target is equally acceptable.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@dstadulis @miketwenty1 @benthecarman @parman_the @barackomaba @murchandamus That, plus the computation of work: https://t.co/mEkc0xS1v9

And where it gets accumulated into nChainWork: https://t.co/auVBoI45ts

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @zeropassio @barackomaba But difficulty is just a rescaling of this (2^256 / target), with scale factor ~(2^48/65535), so just saying "sum of difficulties" will yield the same result.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @zeropassio @barackomaba Technically speaking, difficulty only exists in the human interface; internally, PoW (aka "chainwork") is counted as the sum of (2^256 / target) for a block over all its ancestors, where target equals the maximum acceptable hash value for that block.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@zeropassio @barackomaba A block with more zeroes can come in, but that doesn't mean it has more PoW.

PoW is defined as the sum of the difficulties of blocks in a chain. The difficulty of a block is related to the maximum hash value is is allowed to have, and unrelated to what hash it actually has.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @barackomaba So the answer is B, but the question is based on a misconception. A and B have equal PoW if they have the same difficulty.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@barackomaba The active chain is chosen:
- Among all blocks which are fully valid, and have fully valid ancestors,
- Keep the one(s) with maximum sum of difficulties
- If multiple, pick the earliest first received one

The actual has value is irrelevant. Lower hash does not mean more work.

tweet: @Mario_Gibney Once you permit non-standard things, it becomes impossible to classify. In non-segwit inputs, the script can be anything, and can be consuming anything from the stack. In segwit inputs, future witness versions could do anything, and TR's script versions too.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney No witness and:
- 2 scriptSig elements that look like sig/pubkey: P2PKH (but could be P2SH)
- 1 scriptSig element that looks like sig: P2PK (but could be P2SH)
- Otherwise, P2SH

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney - 1 witness element: P2TR key path
- 2+ witness elements, last of which starts with 0xc0 or 0xc1: P2TR script path
- 2 witness elements that look like sig/pubkey: P2WPKH (actually, could also be P2WSH in theory)
- 2+ witness elements: P2WSH

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney Among (according to current Bitcoin Core) standard inputs, P2TR key path, P2TR script path, P2WPKH, P2WSH are perfectly distinguishable (in case of P2TR, by design). P2PK/P2PKH spends are distinct from each other, but in theory, a P2SH can be constructed that looks like P2PK(H).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@bourbonni @stephanlivera @n1ckler @real_or_random @Blockstream However, this does put a limit on how much can potentially be gained by aggregation methods.

I believe that roughly ~20% of vsize is contributed by witness data currently. Aggregation methods can at best bring that part closer to zero, which in the limit means a 20% increase.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bourbonni @stephanlivera @n1ckler @real_or_random @Blockstream There are no two separate limits for witness and non-witness data. Informally, the only rule is that the sum of vsizes of transactions must not exceed 1M. Thus, the only question for determining capacity impact is the vsizes effect - and aggregation (even half) does reduce vsize.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: For the avoidance of doubt: yes, this is taking into account that the difficulty at the start of the first window is itself the result of a random process, because of the lengths of the blocks preceding it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
* Difficulty adjusts every 2016 blocks, and we assume no rounding or 4x limit
* All block timestamps are an exact Poisson process
* Hashrate is constant

If you'd simulate this, wait a long time, and then randomly pick some range of 104 consecutive windows. What stddev for that?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: (See earlier tweets) Now we know that the long-term standard deviation of the length of a Bitcoin retarget window, under constant hashrate, and idealized difficulty adjustment, is ~10.5 hours, what is the standard deviation for the length of 104 consecutive windows (~4 years)?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: For reference, the correct answer is (b): https://t.co/nRZ8n0x04I

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The mean of a Beta' distribution (https://t.co/Tmofkd1Goq) is a/(b-1) (times 2 weeks, for us), which is indeed 2016/2014 times 2 weeks = 2 weeks 20 min.

The stddev is sqrt(a*(a+b-1)/(b-2))/(b-1), or 2 weeks times sqrt(2*2016*2015/2013)/2014, which is ~10.5 hours.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The correct answer was (b) 10.5 hours.

The length of blocks in the window itself is random, but the difficulty is also random (through the previous window's length, but not further). This yields a ratio of two Erlang distributions, which is a Beta'(a=2016,b=2015) distribution.

But what is its standard deviation?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus The beach tends to have the same ratio of gold/sand as the ocean has, but it's not fixed, and only a tiny fraction of the ocean's sand and gold ends up on the beach. If you search through a piece of beach without finding gold, it doesn't change how much sand you know is elsewhere

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Maybe I can extend the analogy!

The sand on the beach comes from the ocean, where an enormous amount of sand (with a small fraction of gold) circulates. There is a fixed amount of sand and gold in the ocean, but the amount of gold that ends up on the beach is not fixed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus It is correct that X and Y are so large that only a negligibly portion of them ever gets searched. But that is not the explanation for why the expected time to a win doesn't change.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Imagine you (somehow) manage to search through 99% of X without finding any Y. That still would not imply that there is suddenly a much higher ratio of Y/X in the remaining 1%. Instead, it'd means there is likely a surprisingly low amount of Y in that beach.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinWTF @murchandamus If the above helps, stop reading.

But it's actually not the reason. In reality, X and Y are finite (though enormous). X is fixed, but Y is actually not known exactly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @murchandamus @bc1984adam Also note that only making Tor outbound connections makes you far more susceptible to partition/eclipse attacks. It may be desirable from a privacy perspective, but it comes at a cost.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus It doesn't matter how much beach you (or others) have searched through. All you know if that those pieces of beach don't have any gold. It doesn't mean there must be more gold in other pieces of beach.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus In reality it's just that every grain of sand has a 1 in a trillion chance of being gold, independent from every other grain of sand.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus There isn't a fixed amount of Y gold, really. Both X and Y are effectively infinite, but only a tiny portion of sand can get searched through in any reasonable amount of time.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Whenever a new block is found, all miners move on to another beach. There is new gold there, and the location of gold in this new beach has no relation to where it was located in the previous beach.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus There may be faster miners, who can go through patches of sand faster than slower miners. They will, on average, find more gold. But even the slow ones can find gold (though less), because there are no guarantees that any piece of sand contains gold.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Likewise, it would be wasteful for one miner to search a piece of sand another miner has already looked through. Thankfully, the beach is so enormous that there is essentially no chance that two miners ever look in the same spot, even without coordinating with each other.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus It would be wasteful to ever search the same patch of sand twice. If there was no gold in there for the time around, there won't be any gold the second time either.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Miners don't need to remember all the grains of sand they've tried. They just need to remember which patches of beach they've already searched through.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinWTF @murchandamus No miner ever exhausts searching the entire beach. They may finish searching everything in a small piece of the beach, but if so, they'll just move on to another patch of sand.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinWTF @murchandamus While there is only one winner, and only one gold nugget ever identified, there were in fact many, and each of those had a probability of being found.

There is no gaurantee that any particular piece of beach contains gold. More square meters of beach have no gold at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinWTF @murchandamus Think of mining as looking for tiny gold nuggets in a huge sand beach. One in a trillion grains is made of gold.

Every miner picks a piece of beach and starts inspecting grains one by one. The first that finds a piece of gold wins.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@theinstagibbs @achow101 @murchandamus @colemaktypo BIP342 permits a sigcheck per 50 witness bytes, so a block consisting of just tapscripts could do ~80000 signature checks. In a (by current Bitcoin Core) standard transaction it's limited to 1/10th of that.

So roughly 8000-of-n multisig should be possible.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Imagine this (highly contrived) question.

Making a cake takes N hours. At midnight, you start making cakes, one at a time, without breaks in between. How many cakes do you have to make in order to be done by 1am (of some day).

Answer: either N itself, or no solution exists.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
For m=3,4,6,8,12,24 it is the case that for every number x coprime with m, x^2 mod = 1, i.e., they are their own inverse mod m.

E.g.
1*1 mod 8 = 1
3*3 mod 8 = 1
5*5 mod 8 = 1
7*7 mod 8 = 1

No m larger than 24 has this property.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @simulx Because that's the only point where they can decide to stay passive (which makes them powerless) or act a MitM to intercept the connection (which makes them detectable *if* authentication is real).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @simulx It's actually okay that a MitM (or even passive observer) can figure out whether authentication was successful *after* the fact. It's too late by then. The point is only that they shouldn't be able to find out of authentication is desired when the connection is initiated.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @murchandamus The simple observation is that authentication protocols seem to be designed for situations where authentication must succeed, or you don't want a connection at all. The possibilities for when that's not the case seem unexplored so far.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @murchandamus And while mixnets may be part of the solution space for making Bitcoin P2P communication more private, PAPs as described in this write-up aren't specific to Bitcoin or P2P networks at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BobMcElrath @murchandamus I don't see how that's related at all.

This is about optionally authenticating encrypted connections, in such a way that the authentication itself is private. It's not about hiding information origin or whatever on the network.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
7/7 I do hope this can turn into a more formal publication at some point, but in the interest of having something to point to, this write-up is a start.

Thanks to all that contributed to the write-up and ideas it is based on: Greg Maxwell, @real_or_random, and @murchandamus.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 6/7 My interest is specifically in the context of P2P like Bitcoin's, where most connections are random, but sometimes people make deliberate connections (e.g. between their own nodes). We also want to avoid introducing discoverable identities here.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 5/7 The write-up is primarily intended as an introduction to the (interesting, IMO!) problem space and an informal description of the desired cryptographic properties it has. It also lists a few example protocols that achieve them, but proofs are a work in progress.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 4/7 It seems that it is not that hard to construct protocols which achieve this, as well as more far-reaching privacy properties. But at the same time, it does seem like a problem space that's unstudied for now.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 3/7 How to achieve that? All you need is to make sure responders don't learn which (unsuccessful) keys the attempt was for, and treat failed authentication attempts equal to random ones. Then run with random keys if you don't desire authentication.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 2/7 The most surprising part is that if you can make it so that a Man-in-the-Middle cannot tell deliberate connections and random ones apart, the random ones get some protection too: MitMs can't selectively intercept if every connection could be an attempt to authenticate.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
1/7 New write-up: https://t.co/fQhm6QIfVb

Imagine you can encrypt all of an application's P2P network connections, but only some are deliberately to specific peers, while others are just made randomly.

How private can you make an authentication protocol for this use case? Very!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LarsonFarms @wae_chan @murchandamus @Lightlike1 So if there are 10^N nodes, it will inevitably take N steps to reach them at least, and each step involves some small but non-zero delay. Of course, the network isn't perfect and the number of nodes reaches doesn't increase 10x per step, but still, the same argument applies.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LarsonFarms @wae_chan @murchandamus @Lightlike1 It just a result of propagation delays. Imagine every node is connected to 10 other nodes. The miner announces their block to 10 nodes; after they receive it, they can forward it to at most 100 in total; those can send to at most 1000 in total etc.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@LarsonFarms @wae_chan @murchandamus @Lightlike1 More nodes would generally (slightly) worsen these numbers; given constant connectivity, it'll take longer to reach the same proportion of them.

The primary reason is software and protocol improvements, I suspect.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cronokirby @nsatragno Agreed. It's not even sufficient that you not reuse it across algorithms. Just using related nonces is a problem too (e.g. using k and k+1 as nonces). The used-only-once aspect is a part of the requirements, but hardly the only one or the hardest to satisfy one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nvcoelho @nvk @moneyball That particular approach is not feasible against 256-bit keys that are derived from a 128-bit seed using a secure algorithm, but that doesn't mean no other speedup is possible in that case. There may be a proof that it isn't possible, and if so, I'd like to hear it!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nvcoelho @nvk @moneyball For example, if you would actually take a private key in just range [0,2^128), that'd have at most 64-bit security (see https://t.co/WcyezCoiJ4 for attack).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nvcoelho @nvk @moneyball It is true that secp256k1 (or any 256-bit elliptic curve) cannot achieve more than 128-bit DL security (i.e., recovering private key or forging signature). That doesn't mean that there is no benefit to having private keys with more than 128 bits of information in them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinTimO I think that's actually besides the point. I'm not trying to convince anyone that PoW is useful. It is useful to me, and that should suffice. If uselessness according to some is a reason to police it, then I see no reason why we can't police professional sports.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@lmatteis Sure, miners try to increase their rate - by increasing their % of global hashrate (and increasing costs proportionally), they will do so. Scaling multiplies profit.

But airlines do the same: if they increase their passengers (by flying more), they also multiply profits.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@lmatteis The travel industry pays airlines to provide a service, through ticket prices. The airline which does so (proportional to the number of people transported) with the lowest cost will be the most profitable.

The amount paid is bounded by the tickets bought.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@lmatteis The Bitcoin ecosystem pays miners to provide a service, through fees and inflation. The miner which does so (proportional to the hashrate produced) with the lowest cost will be the most profitable.

The amount paid is bounded by the fees paid (for services delivered) and subsidy.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@cryptotruth11 That would be a counterargument if I was trying to convince you PoW is useful. I believe it is, but that is not the point.

The point is that I have no business telling others what they find useful, and neither do you.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @DaveDustpan I obviously don't actually have any objection to people spending their time and money as they see fit - that's the point of my argument. If others see this as useful, so much the better for them.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@kcalvinalvinn @SomsenRuben Obviously! I'm not claiming it is.

I'm just saying that regardless of your model, if you find yourself in a situation where you chose a too low gap limit, the only possible solution is starting over - whatever starting over means in your model.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @kcalvinalvinn You can synchronize from scratch.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @kcalvinalvinn And I mean "rescan" in the most wide sense here. For a node connected to a central index server, it corresponds to asking for more addresses. For a pruned full node, it may mean synchronizing from scratch.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@SomsenRuben @kcalvinalvinn The solution to the gap limit problem is increasing the gap limit.

Sure, some models suffer harder from getting it wrong, as the cost for starting over increases, but fundamentally I don't think this is a big problem. Just rescan with a higher limit, or start off high enough.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@topale22 @IronMetabolism @murchandamus @BitcoinIsSaving @binance @BinanceHelpDesk @cz_binance Not "low"; the chance is exactly 0. Bech32/bech32m protect against up to 4 substitution errors (replacing one character with another).

My guess isn't that they were replacing a character in the address, but incorrectly constructing the output after parsing the address.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf That said, I don't think this is all that related to the original topic here. Sure, an LN implementation can't go misinterpret addresses, but there are plenty of other bugs it could contain that might result in loss of coins.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf In fact, it's one of the things I like about LN (or successors), independent of the commonly mentioned cheap/speed/scalability aspects: it has a real chance of becoming the de-facto payments layer (with the ability to send comments, get instant feedback, ...).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf I very much agree with the fact that Lightning payment UX is far better than the current state with on-chain addresses. BIP70 tried and failed to change that, and I think addresses are now far too entrenched to be replaced for on-chain payments.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @murchandamus @blk014 @IronMetabolism @BitcoinIsSaving @binance @BinanceHelpDesk @cz_binance And furthermore, witness v0 outputs of unknown length are invalid, so even if P2TR were to have used a different length (e.g. 33 bytes as an earlier design did), this "conversion" would have resulted in unspendable outputs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 @IronMetabolism @murchandamus @BitcoinIsSaving @binance @BinanceHelpDesk @cz_binance Though, only if we believe the user's screenshot of the payment app which shows the P2TR address. Otherwise it's not proven that the user themselves didn't perform the "conversion" to P2WSH.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jb55 @theinstagibbs @meshcollider @cz_binance It's definitely a feasible explanation, and it has happened in the past (e.g. P2SH being interpreted as P2PKH). There is a reason we added these to the BIP... https://t.co/EQUNLFp4bb

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 @IronMetabolism @murchandamus @BitcoinIsSaving @binance @BinanceHelpDesk @cz_binance Ha, indeed! Transferrable proof-of-fuckup.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @IronMetabolism @murchandamus @BitcoinIsSaving @binance @BinanceHelpDesk @cz_binance P2TR outputs contain a public key. P2WSH outputs contain a script hash. If you take a valid P2TR output, but use version 0 instead of 1, it'll be interpreted according to P2WSH rules. To spend, you now need a script whose hash equals the P2TR key. If you can, SHA256 is broken.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @meshcollider @cz_binance For various reasons, I believe that's actually what happened here: a P2TR address was entered, and interpreted as P2WSH address with the same payload.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@meshcollider @cz_binance What is worse is that P2TR uses a new checksum algorithm (bech32m), and apparently was accepted. So either:
(1) they're not checking the checksum at all
(2) they implemented bech32m from BIP350 but not the rest of the BIP (and not the test vectors)
(3) this story isn't real.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscarlafarga @joekelly100 @JasonPLowery @mikekelly85 @SatStackingPleb @LorenHodl @FossGregfoss @LukeDashjr Blocks are only kept on disk. Headers are on disk and in memory. Yes, both are kept; that's generally not a DoS risk because of the enormous cost of construct a PoW-valid block (if it's not PoW-valid, even the header won't be kept). Yes, it could flip-flop between the two chain.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@oscarlafarga @joekelly100 @JasonPLowery @mikekelly85 @SatStackingPleb @LorenHodl @FossGregfoss @LukeDashjr Among the set of chains there for which all blocks have been received, the one which is

(a) fully valid
(b) maximal combined PoW
(c) among those, the one with the earliest received tip block as tiebreaker

is treated as the currently-active chain.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscarlafarga @joekelly100 @JasonPLowery @mikekelly85 @SatStackingPleb @LorenHodl @FossGregfoss @LukeDashjr Chains are never discarded. The full tree of all valid & connected headers is kept, along with any block data received for any header therein.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinAustrian @Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben Something something about markets being irrational, and seeing others buy/sell being the primary contributor to you wanting to do the same.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben If circular economies grow, the second category becomes more important, and thus exchange rate becomes more dependent on that usage, and that usage is one that cares about stability, while the former doesn't (at least in the short term).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben An attempt to articulate it: think of all BTC as either being held as a store-of-value (speculatively or not), or being held as being in-flight for payment or being held with the intent of being used as such. Price is a function of how strongly holders care to hold it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben I don't think so... which is why I call it a belief, and would like to see it challenged.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fnietom And at that day-to-day up to month-to-month scale, I don't think it's unrealistic to expect that with sufficiently large circular economies (ignoring whether those are realistic), BTC can be less volatile than the stock market; no one cares about stock as unit of account.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben But I do believe that more circular BTC economies (people paid in BTC, and holding it with the intent of paying others in BTC with it) can provide reduced volatility. I'd like to hear counterarguments for that, though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben Hmm, I don't think I've seen that belief. I think it's quite the opposite even; larger market cap, especially when achieved rapidly, is itself a sign of speculative interest, which can disappear just as rapidly as it appears.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fnietom I'm by no means an expert here, but my long-held belief has been that to reduce (short term) volatility, circular BTC economies are needed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fnietom But when discussing the ability to function as unit of account, I think we generally care about volatility at a much smaller scale (e.g. day-to-day to month-to-month maybe). And at that scale, I don't think BTC is any less elastic than gold is.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fnietom When you talk about volatility, what time scale are you talking about? Most of what you write primarily applies to long-term volatility (e.g. year to year), which I would agree is indeed inherently volatile due to inelasticity of supply.

tweet: @orionwl @kallewoof @La__Cuen This is actually what I like most about Lightning: the fact that it's actually a payment-centric system. It offers instant feedback about whether a transaction is accepted by the receiver, allows metadata to travel along with it, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: fin/ Still, the library had hundreds of merged changes that didn't impact performance. Many of those are maintenance, documentation, keeping CI up to date, tests; I'd like to use that as an example to show there is plenty of work for non-experts, and we welcome contributions!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 6/ libsecp256k1 certainly has had a period where activity wasn't that high, and the recent improvements are a sign this has improved (amongst others, thanks to the new maintainers @n1ckler and @real_or_random, who are far more active than I was).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 5/ The vast majority of these don't have any impact on performance at all, and a few only do so randomly (e.g. by adding a new function, some alignment in the binary is different, or inlining decisions are slightly different, while not having any algorithmic impact).

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl If these assumptions don't hold - and we certainly shouldn't make them absolutes - then yes, there are risks, but that is also no different from a situation where miners go enforce additional rules without ecosystem buy-in, a risk that always exists.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl If miners act rationally, and there actually is social consensus about a change, no significant amount of hashrate is going to be working on blocks that don't enforce the new rules, and the problem of a block with both valid and invalid txn doesn't appear.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl Sure, but those economic nodes also have an incentive to only go along with sufficient assurances that the network won't fork, which is why a large supermajority has to signal for enforcement.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl Yes, but that risk always exists. Miners can always choose to enforce more rules than the rest of the network, and this interferes with the ability to determine whether transactions will confirm, whether or not that's used as an upgrade mechanism.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl And what prevents consensus changes that are harmful is hopefully sane expectations by the ecosystem and transparency.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl I think this whole discussion conflates a technical aspect with a social one. Yes, if the ecosystem migrates to new rules, which you somehow don't like, you have a problem. The only difference between a softfork and a hardfork is in how safe the upgrade is _given consensus_.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl And of course there is the fact that no maintained software exists that doesn't enforce the new rules, which hurts if you'd be hell-bent on running a node that doesn't enforce some softfork you dislike.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@udiWertheimer @jayzio @adam3us @maxtannahill @hampus_s @hasufl Yes, but I'm not sure that's very meaningful: https://t.co/W4pdYYZCJw

There are downsides to having the network enforce more rules than you (e.g. being able to predict propagation of tx), but I don't think validation actually matters.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ColinCareful @khannib @lopp The 2010 inflation bug, yes, not the 2018 one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @khannib @lopp That's true, but its purpose is preventing integer overflow, not inflation as such.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@benediktbuenz And the solution to that is that since P2WSH, script hashes are 256 bits. For the time being, 80-bit collision security is probably fine in practice, but something to be continued.

Still, I don't think a typical (sub-2^80) RIPEMD collision would help the attacker here.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benediktbuenz Right, agreed. There is a known way to exploit that; if you and I construct a 2-of-2 multisig, you say your pubkey is A, and I grind a pubkey B (with known privkey) for which RIPEMD(SHA(<A> <B> CHECKMULTISIG)) == RIPEMD(SHA(<B> CHECKSIG)). Now I can spend the multisig funds.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@cyber_hokie @pete_rizzo_ @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu (1) hurts those who are not willing to invest engineering time
(2) hurts anyone who can't benefit
(3) hurts anyone by increasing risk on coins held by those adopting, possibly hurting the currency in case of a break.
(4) hurts specific people, without technical merit.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@cyber_hokie @pete_rizzo_ @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu Conceptually, for sure, but there are also degrees of disenfranchisement, on a rough scale:
1. new script feature that benefits everyone that adopts it
2. new script version that benefits only some
3. (2) but using new experimental cryptography
4. blacklist someone's coins

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cyber_hokie @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ It cuts both ways. HFs do give the ability to observe unknown rule changes, but at the cost of forcing secession onto those who aren't aware and don't care. In the end, it's not like SFs avoid the ability to secede (look at BCH etc.); it's just not the default.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cyber_hokie @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ Reality is more complicated of course, and there are incentives at the social layer for choosing certain rules that go beyond technical preferences - nobody wants a chain that only they use.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cyber_hokie @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ To me, it's exactly the opposite. In a softfork-upgrade model, everybody gets to pick the rules they like, and those who pick compatible rules get to be in consensus. In a hardfork-upgrade model, you're forcing nodes to pick exactly your rules, or secede.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cyber_hokie @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ If the ecosystem consensus moves to something you disagree with, despite your objections, no technical solution will prevent that from happening.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oorion_ @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ From the perspective of old nodes, segwit did not increase the block size (because they don't see the witnesses).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ And I think perhaps your point of view just boils down to the fact that softforks - ignoring the ecosystem enforcement - is just exploiting the fact that the collective of miners hold censorship rights in the network. That's true, but remains true even if upgrades are hardforks.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ So I think what provides these protections in Bitcoin isn't so much the technique used, but the expectations of the ecosystem around it. If forks (of whatever kind) are expected to be hard, and require a high level of consensus, then they will.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ Also don't forget that a softfork is more than simply a majority of the hashrate enforcing a rule. In order for the rule to take hold, and be reliable, it must be enforced by the ecosystem as well. In this regard, I think it's not so different from a hardfork.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stonecoldpat0 @zhusu @pete_rizzo_ You may argue that even in the latter case, new rules are being introduced that old nodes are unaware of. My position is that for changes like this, this doesn't actually matter, because the rules *they* care about are satisfied: https://t.co/W4pdYYZCJw

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @born2tinkr No, for public keys. Elliptic curve private keys are very easy to make look random (they're uniformly random numbers already); public keys are hard because they're coordinates of points on a curve, which satisfy a particular equation.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: There is a Sage implementation in https://t.co/xMzioZp5zO, which includes exhaustive tests for small curves, as well as a C implementation for the libsecp256k1 library. Benchmarks on Ryzen 5950x are included in the writeup.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: As secp256k1 doesn't meet the criteria for Elligator and Elligator 2, I looked into using Elligator Squared, and found there are a number of optimizations possible. In the writeup I explain them, using Python/Sage pseudocode.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Various approaches exist. One is Elligator and Elligator 2 by @hashbreaker, Mike Hamburg, Anna Krasnova, and @hyperelliptic, which only works for certain classes of elliptic curves. Another is Elligator Squared by @mtibouchi, which works for every curve, but needs more space.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: The purpose of Elligator algorithms: encoding random public keys in such a way that they cannot be distinguished from random bytes. This is useful for running certain protocols covertly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: New writeup: implementing Elligator Squared for BN-like curves: https://t.co/cb14kHVO86

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@i_quadrat So if your goal is "close to uniform output", you need ranges (and/or products of ranges) that are "small" compared to the size of the hash, not just less than.

If your goal is maximal uniformity, any range is fine - but that doesn't mean much in practice.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@i_quadrat Oh, E stands for entropy, not expectation.

So, yes and no. The hash is assumed to be uniform, but it's not technically needed that prod_i(range[i]) <= 2^B; the maximal uniformity property holds even when that is exceeded. However, the quality of what comes out will suffer.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@i_quadrat Whenever range[i] is odd, the whole copy-bits-from-output-to-state step is unnecessary. But whenever it is even, as many bits of entropy are lost as there are zero bits in the bottom of range[i].

Not sure what this precondition refers to. AFAIK, only range[i] < 2**B is needed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @mappum No, just as a replacement for rolling bloom filters (which are used for half a dozen different things in Bitcoin Core, and rather inefficient).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @mappum Yeah, working on a rolling cuckoo filter data structure, which needs to derive both a table index and a fingerprint from the data inserted.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: I ended up writing it up not as a property of the function, but as a property of the resulting distribution (when fed uniform input, and calling it "maximally uniform": https://t.co/HNSXG5zPFy

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @theinstagibbs https://t.co/VYGd2dvWtJ

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
5/5

My proposal:

* start with state = hash(...)
* For i in num_outputs:
  * tmp = state * range[i]
  * out[i] = tmp >> bits
  * state = tmp | (out[i] & (range-1) & ~range)

Each output, as well as their joint distribution, is as close to uniform as possible.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 4/5 But what if you need to map elements not to one, but to two elements in arbitrary ranges? This problem occurs in Cuckoo Filters and the recently-proposed Ribbon Filters. Not only do we want (close to) uniform results, but also results that are (close to) _jointly_ uniform.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 3/5 A much better alternative than modulo is explained on https://t.co/ipS8t23WTD , which uses ((hash * range) >> bits) as reduction function. It has the same uniformity as (hash % range), but is significantly faster.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 2/5 The context: if you have a hash table that doesn't have a power-of-two size, you need to somehow map the hash output to that range. Traditionally, a modulo operation is used, but that's rather slow on modern CPUs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 1/5 I wrote up a neat idea I had for extracting multiple numbers in arbitrary ranges from a single hash, while maximizing uniformity of the output: https://t.co/RamypRy5D7

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt Perhaps one argument against quasi-uniform is that it sounds like it's certainly not actually uniform, while actually uniform is included in this property.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @th_s4m0ht Yes, if some output is reached twice, and another output is not reached at all, the function would not have this property.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt Right, what I mean is clearly not actually uniform - just as close as possible to uniform for functions with the same cardinality. So more like... minimally ununiform?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt The reason for calling it "optimally" uniform: any function with this property is as close to uniform as any function with the same size input and output domains can possibly be.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bascule It's really not a bijection - outputs can have any number of inputs mapping to them, as long as none have more than 1 more than others.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @gwillen There is https://t.co/2n5yL8jnCj, which seems very similar except it has the booleans as codomain, and seems to require exactly equal numbers of inputs mapping to true and false outputs (rather than permitting 1 difference between those).

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille

I was thinking of something like "quasi-uniform" or "near-uniform" or "optimally uniform".

An example of a function that has this property is f(n) = n mod k, for any positive interger constant k.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: I'm looking for a good name for this property: a function for which the minimum and the maximum number of inputs that map to a given output differs by at most 1. Every injective function has this, but it's more general.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kallerosenbaum This is a more generic solution to the overwritten-coinbase problem first partially resolved by (and discussed in) BIP30. Due to the fact that txids commit to transaction ancestors, if all coinbases are unique, all descendant transaction txids will be unique too.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kallerosenbaum There can be at most one coinbase transaction per block, and within one chain, the height of a block is unique. Thus, by including the height in each coinbase, it is impossible to have two identical (same txid) coinbase transactions within one chain (barring hash collisions).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp So instead look at the advantages it brings: smaller on-chain signatures, better incentives for privacy, massively simplifying things like ring signatures over multiple UTXOs (e.g. for proofs of reserve), ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp And I don't think it's reasonable to propose something like this without a reasonable argument that everyone can/should adopt it. It doesn't matter until a large fraction of the circulating supply at least, so if that's not going to happen, better wait longer for better schemes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp I think proposing a PQC scheme for Bitcoin is probably a decade away at least; right now, the costs for adopting are just too high (all PQC schemes have very large keys and/or signatures compared to EC), and lack features.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp Bitcoin has pretty unique requirements in this regard (it cares about verification speed more than signing speed, it cares enormously about the size of signatures, it cares about the ability to build aggregation schemes on top), so an off-the-shelf standard may not fit the bill.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp BIPs there are none, but post-quantum signature schemes are a very hot research topic these days, with pretty fast developments. See for example the recent NIST competition for standardizing one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp And it isn't just you not reusing addresses. If you actually believe a machine exists that can break ECDLP, I think you shouldn't think of BTC as being able to hold much value, with just some non-negligable amount of address reuse going out by others.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp You present using a fresh address for everything transaction as a reasonable option. Even if that's the case, it's insufficient, because that's only a small aspect of revealed public keys; things like multisig, Lightning, various wallet setups, ... all rely on sharing pubkeys.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @alexbosworth I was adding PoW to my emails in the early 2000s. Many spamassassin setups would reduce spam score for emails that had it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp Nearly _everything_ interesting that can be done with Bitcoin, or built on top of it, involves sharing public keys or xpubs with other parties. This isn't going away, and there is no way around it. If you want post-QC protection, build an actual post-QC secure scheme.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tobysharp Using a fresh address isn't enough. You'd need to keep all public keys - including xpubs - hidden from everyone, because in a hypothetical post-QC world, giving someone a public key is equivalent to giving them your money.

tweet: @CypherSkunk88 That's correct. Every point (except the point at infinity) generates the whole group.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@CypherSkunk88 It's difficult.

But this is easy: you can verify that 115792089237316195423570985008687907852837564279074904382605163141518161494337*G = 0 (point at infinity). So the order of G must divide that number. As G != 0, its order cannot be 1. Since it is prime, order(G) must be equal.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @CypherSkunk88 So we know the order of the curve is a prime number, so every subgroup of it is either trivial (1 element) or isomorphic to the group itself (because subgroups must have an order that divides the supergroup). Since the order of G is clearly not 1, it generates the whole group.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @CypherSkunk88 Because we know its order (computed using Schoof's algorithm, but even without, the outcome is easy to verify), and we can factor numbers that big. This one has no factors.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @LukeDashjr @AnoNiMotoX @scottwalker99 @skllzdatklls @_jonasschnelli_ @TheBlueMatt But despite, true PQC for Bitcoin means introducing an actual PQC script mechanism, and migrating to that, and eventually dropping EC support. That latter part might at high cost be done in a non-breaking way (PQC ZKPs of derivation), but won't be usable at scale.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @LukeDashjr @AnoNiMotoX @scottwalker99 @skllzdatklls @_jonasschnelli_ @TheBlueMatt There are interesting interactions between Taproot and QC (e.g. the fact that spending through a key path of a script that has a dummy inner key on itself becomes a transferable proof dat ECDLP is broken).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @LukeDashjr @AnoNiMotoX @scottwalker99 @skllzdatklls @_jonasschnelli_ @TheBlueMatt That works for key path spending, assuming the tweak is secret (which in many cases is a bad assumption; e.g. it'd reduce every multisig to 1-of-n, because all cosigners know the tweak). It doesn't work for script path spending, because those keys aren't tweaked.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @LukeDashjr @AnoNiMotoX @scottwalker99 @skllzdatklls @_jonasschnelli_ @TheBlueMatt Taproot is inherently based on EC, as the scriptPubKey contains an EC point. Introducing PQC scripts will require something else.

In theory there are ways to soft-fork this in on top of Taproot, e.g. require a PCQ ZKP of seed key along with every spend, and later require it.

And there is a lot of work left of course. To make full advantage of Taproot, lots of things need to specced out still:

* MuSig2 standardization so software can cooperate in signing
* Output descriptors, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Thanks to everyone who has helped us get this far - contributors to the BIPs, to the reference code, reviewers of those, ....

But this is also just the beginning. The real work will be in the ecosystem of wallets and other applications adopting changes to make use of Taproot.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Today, that 90% was reached, and the deployment will transition inevitably into locked-in state at the end of this retargetting window. Activation will follow automatically, at block 709632 in November 2021. After that, the rules will be enforced on mainnet, and available for use

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: In April 2021, Bitcoin Core 0.21.1 was released that included the now finalized proposal, including activation mechanism and parameters. The chosen mechanism allowed for a short period of time during which miners can signal readiness. 90% within a window would trigger lock-in.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: A few months later in October the proposal was considered mature and accepted enough to be merged into the Bitcoin Core codebase - without activation - ready to be include in the 0.21.0 release. This allowed testing on testnet without affecting mainnet.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: August 2020 would mark the last semantic change to the proposal, reverting the quadratic residue tiebreaker after realizing it wasn't actually helping performance, and making matters more complicated.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: At the end of 2019, structured review sessions were organized by @bitcoinoptech and @ajtowns, which brought in many eyes (though the number seemed to shrink a bit over time...) and questions, but mostly, I think it helped bring exposure to the ideas in it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: The following months several improvements were made in response to feedback; x-only pubkeys were introduced, the quadratic residuosity tiebreaker was removed, and the sighashing scheme was improved to include all scriptPubKeys being spent.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @thomasbtc A Good Morning.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
But given how fast ideas were evolving, it seemed better to focus on a subset (primarily things usable without interactive setup) + bugfixes + upgrade mechanisms.

In May 2019, @ajtowns, @n1ckler, @real_or_random, and I published the first drafts of these BIPs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
At the time there were so many ideas even for "structural" Script improvements (not counting ideas for new opcodes); there was cross-input signature aggregation, graftroot, g'root, of course Taproot itself, ...

Initially my hope was to create one proposal that did all of them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: A few months later, a few people including me started writing a specification to focus on this idea as an upgrade to Bitcoin's script capabilities. There were so many ideas, but we couldn't realistically include everything in one proposal.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It's been a long story, that started in a diner in Los Altos, CA where in Greg Maxwell, Andrew Poelstra and I somewhere in January 2018 had lunch.

While I briefly had to leave the table, they had come up with a really cool idea to hide Merkle roots in P2PK-like outputs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: As of block 687284, Taproot signalling has reached 1815 blocks this period, guaranteeing that absent very deep reorgs, it is guaranteed to lock in. Following that, it will activate at block 709632, probably around mid-November 2021.

tweet:
@ajtowns @r0ckstardev @NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus That sounds correct to me.

I think in general you'll want more-or-less matching output types for payments and change, so the slight cost increase of change would be offset by the decreased cost of spending incoming payments.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@r0ckstardev @NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus P2TR outputs are 12 vB larger than P2WPKH outputs.

For inputs it obviously depends on what you're doing. See @murchandamus's https://t.co/aSMQoNjurU for an analysis perhaps.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus For change it's more complicated. The privacy argument initially will of course favor existing output types, but hopefully that too will change over time.

And even if absolute number of P2WPKH exceed P2TR, there is a slight privacy gain in P2TR: simple payment or not is hidden.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus For payments, it's cheaper, so from a purely economical perspective there is no reason no to switch apart from engineering cost, and perhaps concerns about senders being compatible with the address format - which should go away over time.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus And while P2TR outputs are larger than P2WPKH outputs, they are the same size as P2WSH outputs - which presumably senders are already ok with.

For change, it's a harder question as you're both the sender and spender.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@NicolasDorier @benthecarman @BitcoinIsSaving @murchandamus That's correct, but irrelevant for payments, as the sender pays for the output.

As a receiver, you only care about the cost of spending, which is slightly lower for P2TR than P2WPKH.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Unfortunately, I don't have any great intuitive insight that explains why the average is 1/(N+1). You could say something like that a "typical" placement of hashes in the interval will put the hashes at the boundaries of N+1 equally sized ranges... but that's very handwavy.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Why is the answer not exact? Hashes (interpreted as number) produce integers of course, not real numbers, so to answer the real question we must work with a discrete probability distribution, which complicates matters a lot. However, the values we work with for T are huge.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The value of (min_hash / T), averaged over all 340 periods, would therefore have the expected value of 1/2017, but with standard deviation around 1/37210.

@achow101 got 1/1780 when measuring this (https://t.co/I3vSomUQy8). That's ~2.4 standard deviations from the expected value.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Now, it also has a standard deviation of T/2018, which is relatively speaking very large (same magnitude as the average). So if you'd measure it for individual retargetting periods, you'll get numbers all over the place.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: So what is that distribution? https://t.co/yAlWHltoCB explains: the minimum of variables >= y whenever each individual variable >= y. From this, you can derive that the probability density for minimum of 2016 f(x) = 2016/T*(1-x/T)^2015. It has expected value T/2017.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It's worth pointing out that this question is not concerned with retargetting or hashrate. It may match the difficulty, or not, and may even change during the window.

Some number of hashes were performed in the period, and 2016 of them were below T; those are uniform in [0,T]

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The correct answer is: T/2017 (not exactly exactly, but negligibly close to it).

If we approximate hash outputs as uniformly distributed real numbers in [0, T], we want to know the distribution of the minimum of 2016 independent samples from it.

tweet: @shaoner It's not clear if it's necessarily a win, but I believe in very early benchmarks it appeared to be better. The downside is of course that you need more multiplication operations when multiplying.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shaoner You mean why use 5x52 instead of 4x64 bits, or 10x26 instead of 8x32 bits?

Using such non-normalized representations allows you to perform certain operations without carry. E.g. you can multiple a field element with a small constant, or add/subtract them without carry.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @real_or_random @fiatjaf @n1ckler Fair point. I guess my assumed model only allows the fault injector to make random mutations, so a sufficiently large counter would be very unlikely to ever collide.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf @n1ckler @real_or_random Let me know if I made any mistakes above.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf Actually, another side note here: I should have said power-measuring side channel attacks here, not timing attacks. Timing attacks can be prevented generically using safe algorithms. Preventing power-based side channels is much harder - but aux randomness obscures them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf Or maybe put more concretely, as randomness at signing time can be avoided with MuSig2 using a stateful counter, MuSig-DN avoids the need for any state at all inside or between signing sessions. That's really cool, but the ZKP makes it not so practical.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf MuSig-DN doesn't have this requirement - it can securely construct deterministic nonces, with no randomness at all at runtime. It comes at a heavy price though (a pretty heavy zero-knowledge proof that all participants did so correctly), which is like a ~1000x slowdown.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf If you have a stateful signer (one that has an incorruptibly secure memory that is retained between unrelated signing sessions; not just between 1st and 2nd round of one session) you can easily work around this: keep a stateful counter, and use H(counter++,privkey) as nonce.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@fiatjaf Side note: "measuring" randomness is hard.

https://t.co/ey8icjx1HT

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf In practice, that's terrible - true randomness at signing time is non-trivial. Not so much technically hard, but history has shown that lots of things break in practice. Furthermore, it's also very annoying to test. You can't observe that randomness isn't good.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf Then about MuSig2. As presented in the paper: you have only one option: the nonce must be completely random. The tiniest bit of information the attacker has about it (e.g. they know the 137th bit has 51% chance of being a 1 instead of 50%) technically breaks the proof.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf How do you measure the quality of randomness? In short, the smaller the probability the attacker can guess your randomness the better. Most desktop computer CPUs these days contain hardware to generate true randomness (assuming you trust the manufacturer of course).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf For fault injection attacks, I believe it is sufficient if the auxiliary randomness is merely non-repeating, so a stateful counter that is incremented on every signing attempt, and never reused would suffice. For timing attacks, all randomness helps - however good you can.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf If you're concerned however about timing attacks (e.g. your hardware wallet is secure but the computer it's connected to is not, and it can extremely accurately measure the time it takes to sign), or fault attacks (attacker can electrocute the device), auxiliary randomness helps.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@fiatjaf Note that BIP340 is purely about single-key signatures. The requirements for MuSig2 are very different.

Also note again that BIP340 is a synthetic nonce scheme, so under traditional attacker models, it's completely fine to use no randomness at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf So BIP340 suggests what's called a synthetic nonce scheme, which is a function of key, msg + auxiliary randomness. The randomness improves resistance against side channels and fault attacks, but traditional security remains even without (or with very crappy) auxiliary randomness.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf Really what you want is "derandomization": a scheme that is secure without randomness at signing time. Deterministically computing the nonce from msg & key is one way of doing that, but it also precludes the ability to improve further using randomness.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@fiatjaf I think it's more correct that it does use them: BIP340 starts with a deterministic formula, but then *additionally* allows (and encourages) adding additional entropy to it.

The scheme is perfectly secure under a traditional attack model if no additional entropy is used.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @liber_liver @fiatjaf @real_or_random That's all correct, but it isn't the reason why BIP340 doesn't use them (BIP340 only specifies single signer signing, not MuSig or any other multisignature, so the argument doesn't apply).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@orionwl @anguschampion @pmullr It says weight, not mass. So presumably they're talking about Earth-gravity-equivalent newtons, instead of kg.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@raknifln @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden With key aggregation only the aggregated key ends up on chain, with one signature.

With (CI)SA you have multiple public keys on chain (at least one per output being spent, you can't have outputs without keys!), and then one signature for all of them together.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @Truthcoin @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden There are lots of different ways to classify those mechanisms. Interactive/noninteractive, conjunction/disjunction/something else, key-representable/other, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @Truthcoin @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden There are different tools too, of course. The Taproot tweak permits a disjunction between a (key-representable) policy and an arbitrary one. Threshold schemes like FRONT permit k-of-n represented as a key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney @Truthcoin @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden The MAST part is effectively permitting a disjunction of policies, but I wouldn't call it aggregation. MuSig (or other key aggregation) is a conjunction of policies (which have to be keys, not scripts).

Both are useful for constructing on-chain policies, but different ones.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@RobertSpigler @murchandamus @theinstagibbs @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Conceptually, it's so simple you'll probably call it cheating.

How do we interactively construct a 1-of-2 pubkey?
Answer: you generate a new key and give it to me. Done.

If you want non-interactivity, you're restricted to e.g. putting them in separate branches of a Merkle tree.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@murchandamus @RobertSpigler @theinstagibbs @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden MuSig (1 & 2) can only do n-of-n policies in one key.
FROST can do any k-of-n policies (but with interactive setup). Techniques exist for arbitrary monotonic boolean functions in general, though building protocols for doing those securely is probably nontrivial.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @raknifln @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden To make matters even more confusing and full circle: it's also possible to build a signature agg. scheme out of a key aggregation scheme. In that case, you effectively do get Schnorr signatures on chain, but they're verified against on-chain keys - aggregated at verification time

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @raknifln @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Cross-input aggregation means different consensus rules that allow for signatures (which are technically not Schnorr signatures anymore, but something related like Bellare-Neven signatures, see https://t.co/DQKvzyBo7z) with multiple keys (from distinct inputs).

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dustin_dettmer @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Really, it's not like you misunderstand anything. I'm splitting hairs about terminology (and even then, it's questionable, see https://t.co/ImQcGq39TN).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @theinstagibbs @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Definitely.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden In MuSig, you essentially use H(A,{A,B})*A + H(B,{A,B}*B as aggregate. The fact that every input key affects the factor of every other key proved sufficient to make this secure.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden So we can't just sum the key. Our first attempt (https://t.co/Lx4YFduROQ) was multiplying each key with its hash. So the agg of A and B would be H(A)*A + H(B)*B. This later turned out to be completely broken.

MuSig was the fix for this.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney @SomsenRuben @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden This is actually how MuSig came about.

The problem is rogue key attack:
* You have key A, and a UTXO to it.
* I have key B, and create a low-value UTXO for key B-A.
* I create a spending tx spending both, signing with the sum (B-A)+A = B, which I can sign without you.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Perhaps it's wrong for me to say there isn't any signature aggregation; if you use MuSig, you're ultimately producing an aggregated signature.

What I mean to say is that the consensus rules of Taproot or Schnorr don't have any awareness of aggregation.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Signature aggregation implies a verification algorithm that receives a list of (message,pubkey) pairs and a signature.

I guess key aggregation can be seen as a special case of it, where the aggregated signature is also a valid "single key" signature for the aggregated key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden You're probably better off with just multiple 2-of-2 MuSig aggregated keys in 3 leaves of a Merkle tree, if you want accountability.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Why is key aggregation better? Because it means the original keys never end up on chain. With signature aggregation you still have on-chain keys, but with 1 signature.

Downside: key aggregation cannot be used cross input, as you can't predict which UTXOs will be spent together.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden Of course, key aggregation has an impact on the signing algorithm, and that's probably one of the main reasons why it's useful to do it before CISA: the work needed to support MuSig signing in wallet will take a while, but it's pretty similar to CISA signing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney @raknifln @rocket_fuel_ @gladstein @Snowden There is no signature aggregation at all, cross-input or not.

Schnorr signatures however support key aggregation through MuSig or related schemes (which is way better than signature aggregation, but is done at address creation time, not signing time).

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Gabridome @alexbosworth This interacts nicely with Taproot, as it allows hiding that escape hatch script unless it is actually necessary. But you can use adaptor signatures also directly in a script - in that case it'll just always be clear on chain that there is an escape hatch.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Gabridome @alexbosworth Well, let me be more rigorous.

An adapter signature is just a way of jointly constructing a signature that ends up on chain. But if you want to use an adapter signature for atomic swaps, you need a script that lets the funder get his funds back after some period of time.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@HillebrandMax @ffstls @wasabiwallet If the client is offline for a substantial period of time, their mempool will be very out of date/empty. So set reconciliation won't help you.

If you want something private, I think there are two options:
* Just ask for and download the whole mempool
* PIR cryptography

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @johndreich @alexbosworth A few things (which likely won't end up in typical end-user wallets, but may be internally used in say post-taproot Lightning protocols) do need interactivity (i.e., you need to negotiate with other parties before constructing addresses, and store information).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @johndreich @alexbosworth Anything more complex that involves either multiple parties or multiple devices... you obviously need information about those other parties or devices too. For most features targetted by Taproot, their xpubs + information about the setup (+ your own key) suffices.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @johndreich @alexbosworth Well, it depends. If you just want a single-key wallet that can send and receive without multisig or whatever, just a seed phrase suffices (though, with information that it's for a taproot wallet - and no standards for that exist yet).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Gabridome @alexbosworth It's the same thing.

The taproot construction is not revealed to the network as long as the happy-everyone-agrees spending is used. Same for adaptor signatures: if the opposing party stalls, you have to reveal it had an escape hatch (and get your coins back after a delay).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ffstls @HillebrandMax The question is vague. The goal of transaction relay is of course to bring - to the extent possible - mempools in sync already. Erlay is an improvement to the tx relay protocol, thus ultimately it's an optimization to mempool synchronization.

It just isn't doing that directly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinAustrian @alexbosworth Yes, all public keys can be aggregates of other keys, regardless of where they occur (inner key, or keys inside scripts).

Multiparty ECDSA can sort-of achieve the same thing today actually, though it is far less complicated with Schnorr.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @alexbosworth And... what about the taproot feature itself? The fact that it merges P2PK and P2SH style constructions in one, being indistinguishable as long as the key-path spend is used. That's the most interesting aspect of it I think...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @alexbosworth Listing signature aggregation here is perhaps a bit confusing. The included Schnorr signatures make key aggregation simpler (MuSig etc), but that isn't the same as signature aggregation (it's decided at key generation time, not at signing time).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinBellyB @jmp_moon @Cairo_mairo @janrothen @jack Perhaps you're confusing with the GLV optimization patent: https://t.co/UbT3CPWhWb. That's independent of Schnorr (it also helps with ECDSA), and is an entirely optional local optimization with no impact on the network.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinBellyB @jmp_moon @Cairo_mairo @janrothen @jack Schnorr's patent expired in 2008 or 2009, if I remember correctly. It just wasn't implemented because there was no established standard for doing so. It's not as easy as "take Schnorr, implement it"; there are many ways to do that, with various trade-offs. See BIP340 for ours.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@swyx JPEG to JPEG-XL conversion can be done with existing encoding software; it uses the predictor function like every other way of encoding JPEG-XL does.

In fact, JPEG-XL was designed to support lossless transcoding from JPEG (so it can be decoded to a byte-for-byte identical JPEG).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Nuighon @jonsneyers @arikaleph The predictor language is definitely not Turing complete; it's just a decision tree based on some pixel properties (nearby color values, coordinates) with leaves that are offsets from a few base predictors.

But: the images produced are; they are essentially automaton evaluation.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fxthoorens There are _many_ examples that for some reason incorporate Sierpinski-like patterns. That's not a surprise,  they can be described by cellular automata, and the predictor language can encode those easily. See also https://t.co/HAXTLozI4h, about FLIF (predecessor to JPEG-XL).

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
JPEG-XL (a freshly-standardized proposed successor to JPEG) has a tiny language in it to encode a prediction function (guess next pixel from previous). Images that are _exactly_ this prediction are super small, and can be pretty artsy.

This one is amazing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BreakingFrancis @adam3us @yojoots @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles Verifying and signing of both ECDSA signatures and Schnorr signatures all need a modular inverse. We're making modular inverses faster. Thus, signing and verifying both signatures types get faster too.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @yojoots @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles Batch verification of BIP340 has no inversions at all, but that comes at the cost of a point decompression (getting R.x and R.y from r), and then redoing the computation with just points.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @yojoots @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles So!
ECDSA sign: inversion mod p (for computing R.x from k).
ECDSA verify: inversion mod n (for computing 1/s).
BIP340 sign: inversion mod p (for computing R.x from k).
BIP340 verify: inversion mod p (for computing R.y from jacobian R).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @yojoots @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles That's true for some variants of Schnorr signatures, but not for single-verification in BIP340.

The reason is that you need to check the evenness of the Y coordinate of the computed R point. This requires converting to affine coordinates, which needs inversion mod p (not mod n).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @yojoots @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @adam3us @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles That's not true. libsecp256k1 includes BIP340 Schnorr signing and verification support too, and they use the same internals (like modular inverses). So it also benefits from these improvements (as do key generation and ECDH). The benefits are just most impactful for ECDSA.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bjarnemagnussen @Blockstream @adam3us @Excellion @LarryBitcoin @Snyke @rusty_twit @Seardsalmon @nwoodfine @notgrubles Yes, it does. The savings are smaller there, but they exist (around 12% for signing, and around 7% for verifying).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @alevchuk Code review, reasoning about things that can go wrong about its assumptions, and where possible: formal proofs of correctness.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nikitab @sanket1729 Yes, it's a variant of binary GCD. Differences include an invariant that the first variable is always odd (which is maintained in every step), and not actually comparing the variables (which requires access to high-order bits). Instead, delta tracks knowledge about magnitudes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nikitab @sanket1729 For a more complete description of the algorithm, and how it is made constant-time, see https://t.co/xMXLTE1R14 (it's explained using Python, which is obviously never constant-time, but hopefully it's close enough to see how the corresponding C is).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jigawatt1211 The new safegcd-based inversion implementation actually has both a constant-time and a variable-time version which is 1.5x faster. Validation uses the variable-time one; signing and key generation use the constant-time one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@jigawatt1211 Validation never needs constant-timeness at all, as it doesn't involve any secret data.

libsecp256k1 today has two inversions: a ladder, and a libgmp based variable time one. The latter is disabled in Bitcoin Core to avoid consensus depending on libgmp, so it always uses ladder.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 Remove the "g & 1" after "else".

name: Pieter Wuille

https://t.co/l1QwI4ZAzC

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
And the solution translates then to:

* N is any even number.
* Number the teams from 0 to N-1.
* Number the days from 1 to N-1.
* On day d:
  * Team 0 plays team d.
  * For t not {0,d}: team t plays team 1 + ((2d-t-1) mod (N-1)).

For N=2^k, t plays (t xor d) also works.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It just occurs to me that this problem I had a while ago can also be formulated as:

You have N teams, and N-1 days. Every day, every team plays one match against another team. Every combination of two teams has to play exactly once.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dustin_dettmer Yes, you can use a method that takes msg, key, randomness as input, and is secure even without good randomness (but offers better side-channel resistance if there is). RFC6979 can take in auxiliary data; so does BIP340's nonce function.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@hamal03 Yes, but not "again". MuSig is for multisignatures, RFC6979 is for single party signatures. There is no overlap.

MuSig-DN (https://t.co/XyGoxDO0tM) suggests a way of constructing multisignatures without randomness at signing time, but at a high cost.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@dustin_dettmer *Using* randomness if you have it, sure.

Using a scheme whose security critically relies on randomness when it can be avoided, hell no.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Serianox_ @matthew_d_green @BearSSLnews @goldbe You absolutely need the private key (or some other secret information) in the nonce function, otherwise it is predictable to the attacker.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @matthew_d_green @BearSSLnews @goldbe Just 22 SHA256 compressions, not 22 HMAC invocations. And it accounts for 10-15% of the total signing time on my hardware now. Part of that is due to the SHA256 code in libsecp256k1 being far less optimized than everything else, so it could be improved significantly.
