name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @orionwl @LukeDashjr As for where it matters... I can imagine it becomes a bottleneck for Lightning transaction rate for example, especially on lower-powered hardware (but I don't actually know).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @orionwl @LukeDashjr That doesn't mean it's really a problem. In many use cases, signing is more than fast enough. In cases where it isn't, there are solutions (precomputed nonces, use hardware acceleration, use a different scheme...), but they add engineering cost, and shouldn't be needed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @orionwl @LukeDashjr What triggered this was mostly the observation that after the latest improvements, 15% of the signing time would be spent in a computation that has no business even being a consideration at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_benma_ Convincing people that it's just as safe as the de facto standard :)

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman In case it isn't clear, nonce_seed=H(msg) means everyone just knows the nonce for every signature. ECDSA nonces don't just need non-reuse, they need to be completely unpredictable to the attacker.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bitbrothersvzla Someone once wrote a document about how people should be creating digital signatures. It's great, and I'm very happy it is actually used. But it's a little bit overkill, making signing slightly slower than it could have been without impacting security - in my personal opinion.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman nonce_seed=H(msg) is very broken. You need the private key in there (or something else that isn't publicly known). The question is how.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman The big thing that HMAC protects against that many (real world) hash functions don't is length-extension attacks. But I don't see how those are relevant if key and message are constant length.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman With constant-size inputs a and b, I believe that HMAC(key=a,msg=b) and H(a||b), under reasonable assumptions for H, have pretty much exactly the same security properties.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman I don't think it actually helps with that, but I can only speculate on the actual reasons.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @nicksdjohnson @aantonop It's based on the standard HMAC DRBG construction, a very conservative choice. Also not a bad idea to start from well-researched primitives, if you don't care about performance...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @GonzaloLabin With RFC6979, ECDSA signatures don't need any randomness at all at signing time. You of course still do need randomness at key generation time, though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@TheBTCGame @GonzaloLabin It probably only matters if you're trying to produce many signatures per second, especially on low-powered hardware.

And if it really matters, there are ways around it: hardware acceleration, more optimization, or simply using something else. But that shouldn't be necessary...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @GonzaloLabin It depends what hardware you're on, and much how effort you spend on making it fast. My point is more that it's needlessly complicated for what it does. I give numbers elsewhere in the thread.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @goldbe We could also ask @BearSSLnews directly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @goldbe I suspect the answer is that RFC6979 is starting very generically, from a well-defined preexisting HMAC-based PRNG, and then instantiating specifically for nonces. That approach is pretty conservative and defensible I think - if you ignore efficiency.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
So, I love that RFC6979 helped us get rid of the notion of needing high-quality randomness at signing time for ECDSA, but from a performance perspective the specific choices are a bit disappointing.

</rant>

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
So eh... why is there is no standardized generic solution that e.g. computes the nonce by just hashing key and msg (and possibly iterating if out of range)?

This is pretty much what is done in more modern "all in one" specifications like Ed25519.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: But once you include the possibility of optional hardware support, lots of improvements are possible for all code (e.g.  none of it currently uses SSE4/AVX2 at all). So I think it still gives some indication of how wasteful RFC6979 is - computing a nonce should be trivial.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: This isn't an entirely fair comparison. The SHA256 implementation is relatively naive pure C code, while other pieces of code have undergone extensive optimization (including a small bit of x86_64 assembly). Much faster SHA256 code exists, especially on hardware with SHA-NI.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: With some in-progress improvements (safegcd modular inverses, signed-digit multi-comb multiplication) in libsecp256k1 included, an ECDSA signature takes 32.3 s on my Zen+ CPU. 4.9 s of that is spent in the RFC6979 nonce computation.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: It's easy to think of hashes as "fast things", and the rest of the work involved in creating a signature (which needs elliptic curve arithmetic) as "slow things"... making it easy to forget to look at actual numbers.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Conceptually, it's defining a hash from (message, key) to (nonce).

In more detail, it's instantiating an HMAC-based PRNG, seeding it with message/key, and extracting trial nonces from it. One nonce costs *22* invocations of the SHA256 compression function!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
So... RFC6979, which specifies derandomized nonces for ECDSA (essentially computing them deterministically from the message and the private key).

It's a good idea, and a success: widely deployed, and it probably actually prevented real-world security problems.

But... it's slow.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscpacey @hasufl @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi And in particular, someone who branches off from a block in 2009, creating a very long low-difficulty chain off it, still can't make you switch to their chain. That's obvious, but it needs the "heaviest chain" rule. And in this scenario there are difficulty adjustments in between

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscpacey @hasufl @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi It is still heaviest chain, not longest chain. If you have a fork that lasts long enough to include a difficulty adjustment, the side with higher difficulty (at the same height) will win. In extreme situations the shorter chain may have more work, even (and thus, win).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscpacey @NicolasDorier @hasufl @LucasNuzzi That has several downsides: enormous variance (you'd need way more confirmations to have confidence a block won't get reorged out), and lots of opportunities for selfish mining (a low block hash becomes something you want to keep secret).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@oscpacey @NicolasDorier @hasufl @LucasNuzzi Every valid block is equally hard to produce, as all you need is a block whose hash is below the target.

If you'd say say work=2^256/blockhash, you would occasionally, and with no merit from the miner, hit a block that is spectacularly worth more than others.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @oscpacey @hasufl @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi No, work = 2^256/(target). All blocks with the same difficulty have the same amount of work.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ajtowns @murchandamus @glozow @robot__dreams https://t.co/3RaAYL2WVC

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ajtowns @murchandamus @glozow @robot__dreams It's one billionth of an ACK.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @San_person @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl @Vertcoin I have no clue.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi Yes, almost always it will be the case that blocks at the same height have the same amount of PoW, because their difficulties are equal. Only if the forks spans a retarget (difficulty adjustment) will the branches have a different amount of work.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl You could say that you still only count work as 2^256/target, but in case of ties, use lowest hash at the tip as tiebreaker. This has still an issue: a miner who finds a remarkably low hash could just wait to announce it, making others waste work he can wipe out.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl So work is counted as (2^256/target_hash). If you'd change that to (2^256/actual_hash), you just introduce variance for no good reason: occasionally a miner on a minority fork could mine a surprisingly low hash, and wipe out several majority fork blocks, for example.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl Work (as in PoW) is measured based on the expected number of attempts that were needed to produce the block. All hashes below the target are valid, so all have an equal amount of work associated with them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl That evidence comes in the form of seeing blocks built on top. If you see others spent work on building on top of a block you didn't think was first, you'll change your mind.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl So which one do you pick as a node in a global network, without the ability to tell which one was really first? You *don't*. You *guess* that the one you saw first was actually first, but you're ready to change your mind if you see evidence that others saw differently.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl So any time two miners find competing blocks within seconds of each other, there is a reasonable chance that some part of the network hears one first, and another part hears the other one first.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl Of course, in reality this is made much more significant by the fact that blocks incur processing and network infrastructure delays while propagating. A node may not hear about a new block until several seconds after it was mined, even on good networks.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl This difficulty is inherent: simply due to the laws of relativity, it is simply impossible to determine which event occurred first to distinct observers: information cannot travel faster than the speed of light. If two blocks are mined sufficiently close, a fork will occur.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl Resolving this question is the entire point of PoW: any individual node cannot possibly decide what the valid chain is going to be. Which blocks appears first for some nodes is not necessarily the same as what other nodes see.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl If that's not the case, it is indeed the order in which the blocks were received that matters (first wins). However, that is a local decision, made by every node individually, and doesn't determine which block will actually win.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier @LucasNuzzi @hasufl If the total work between the two branches differs, the one with higher work always wins. This only happens if the split traverses a retarget (i.e. spans a block with height that's a multiple of 2016).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Thanks to everyone who has contributed to the code, write-up, benchmarking, and review so far, including Peter Dettman (obviously), Greg Maxwell, @real_or_random, @sanket1729, @murchandamus, Russell O'Connor, and others.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
I started this Python based write-up as a set of notes detailing my understanding of the whole thing, and as a help for (other) reviewers to do more quickly. And also because it's just an awesome algorithm...

So, it's there if someone is interested.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: This is primarily code written by Peter Dettman, who also came up with most of the techniques of making an efficient C implementation. I've just been taking on the task of getting it cleanly integrated into libsecp256k1, modularizing/refactoring it, plus some moderate speedups.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
I've tweeted about this before, because we made some interesting discoveries in the process of looking into it.

https://t.co/BQPIQ3BDV3

Note that this improvement, for the sake of not overburdening review, is not yet included in the PR and write-up.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
We care about this algorithm because it's a remarkably good trade-off between performance and simplicity. Currently libsecp256k1 uses a slow exponentiation ladder for constant-time inverse, and libgmp (if enabled) for vartime.

This lets us drop the (optional) libgmp dependency.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It won't break any speed records like this implementation:

https://t.co/LaWoB8igC9

But hopefully a lot easier to review (and will run on many more systems). The constant-time version is around 1.5x to 2x slower than their code.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: The actual implementation is pure C, no asm (except for optional 64*64->128 bit multiplication, and reliance on two's complement) of the algorithm, both with a constant-time and variable-time version (which can optionally use __builtin_ctz if available).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
A write-up on the safegcd implementation (mostly by Peter Dettman) we've been working on getting into libsecp256k1:  https://t.co/xMXLTE1R14 (not yet merged, URL is not stable).

It explains most optimizations by building them step by step in Python.

As for why it converges so much faster... I don't have any great insight.

But the diagram below (left=original, right=mutated) looks a lot prettier, right? https://t.co/ZFeO6R62f7

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
I should clarify that the final version wasn't actually what he randomly stumbled upon. Once we learned that small tweaks existed that had better bounds, we started looking for more, and found even better.

Original: ~2.8 steps/bit
Mutation: ~2.5 steps/bit
Final: ~2.3 steps/bit

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: For context, this is an unusual algorithm that can be made constant-time (a requirement in cryptographic applications for side-channel resistance) by simply always running the maximum number of iterations rather than stopping when done.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Now, I had just come up with a technique to generally find upper bounds on how many iterations this algorithm needs (see link in top tweet). It was easy to adapt it to this mutated version... and found it only needed 590 iterations (where the original may need 723).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Looking into it in more detail, I didn't expect this would actually break anything, but just make it slower to finish.

So with that, he started looking for cases that were specifically slow under this mutation, to add those as a test. He couldn't find any...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
In order to build interesting test cases, Greg tried mutation testing: introduce intentional bugs in the code to see if our tests would catch it.

He noticed that changing a "<" into "<=" didn't break any tests.

tweet: @_love_bkk @RobertSpigler Hardware wallets need to support this protocol. If they don't, there is no way to enforce honest behavior.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@pavolrusnak @n1ckler @BTC_Vigilante @Trezor This isn't a vulnerability, as it's addressing a security risk that isn't part of the security model.

Instead, it's a very cool protocol that allows hardware wallets to remain secure even when the security model is expanded to (one of HW wallet / SW wallet is honest).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@pavolrusnak @n1ckler @BTC_Vigilante @Trezor Yes, if you trust your hardware wallet to not leak information, then measures to prevent it from doing so are of course unnecessary. Whether that's an acceptable assumption is up to the user.

This mechanism prevents a hardware wallet from leaking keys even if it is not trusted.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ZKsimulator for k=1, n=4: the sum of the first 4 elements of L is 1/2.

For k=0, n=0: the sum of the first 0 elements of L is 0.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Context: L[i] is the rate of entropy produced by the i'th extractor in an optimal layout of an advanced multi-level Von Neumann extractor (see https://t.co/cb9KWHMc7R).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Let L be the list formed by concatenating fib(i) entries equal to 1/2^(i+1). So L is [1/4, 1/8, 1/16, 1/16, 1/32, 1/32, 1/32, 1/64, ...].

It appears that for any natural number k, an n exists such that sum(L[i], i=0..n-1) = 1-1/2^k. Is this obviously true?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MeniRosenfeld @DavidVorick Indeed, that's exactly how I solved it. However I found https://t.co/sltK1Af1us.

So in short this means that as the length B goes to infinity, there will be on average 2^(-K-1) subsequences of at least K consecutive zeroes per bit.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@danrobinson @DavidVorick 1

0110010000110 has 4 times K=1, 2 times K=2, 1 time K=3, 1 time K=4.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @DavidVorick But how many in function of the length? Given a sequence of B uniformly random bits, what is the expected value for the number of subsequences of consecutive 0s of at least length K?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @dstadulis @orionwl @DavidVorick Shaken, not stirred.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick ... without ever knowing, measuring, or even having any clue at all, about what p is.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick The crazy thing is that if you do this for sufficiently many layers deep, you basically extract *all* the entropy in your original input. Doesn't matter how biased; it can extract arbitrarily much of the -(p*log2(p)+(1-p)*log2(1-p)) Shannon entropy in it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick Here is the principle behind multi-level VNE:

Input 0 0: out -; feedA 0; feedB 0
Input 0 1: out 0; feedA 1; feedB -
Input 1 0: out 1; feedA 1; feedB -
Input 1 1: out -; feedA 0; feedB 1

Out is the entropy you produce. feedA and feedB are inputs to two new VNEs. Now recurse.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick But if for some reason you absolutely want guaranteed-100%-pure-pristine entropy without any computational hardness assumptions attached, VNEs are magic. Especially multi-level ones.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick If you have a computer, and have a lower bound on how unpredictable the input is, feeding it through a cryptographic hash function, you'll end up with practically better randomness than what a (simple) VNE can do.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @DavidVorick I think one answer is that in a computer setting it really only matters if you have potentially very biased inputs, or if you demand information theoretical security.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @DavidVorick Yeah, not arguing that you should use VNEs instead, only that they accomplish a fundamentally different thing. Given the iid assumption, the toss distribution is completely irrelevant and you don't even need to measure it: you always get 100% entropy.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @DavidVorick That's a very ambitious and probably excessive goal in the real world, but it is a property you can't replicate with statistics. What you produce is very likely sufficiently unpredictable to an attacker - and that's what matters - but can't give a 100% guarantee.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@DavidVorick Ah, I only skimmed it at first and saw you mention Von Neumann extractors so I thought you were using them.

The single advantage such extractors have (assuming independent and identically distributed tosses) is that what comes out is actual information-theoretical entropy.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@DavidVorick This one is better: https://t.co/gXqO3f9Uxm 

4.5 bits per 8 coin tosses (if unbiased).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @DavidVorick It's also... not very good. 2.7 bits per 4 dice rolls is kind of ridiculous. Trying to actually use extra information from the 6 faces rather than just 2 from coinflips mostly increases the table size without adding much extraction.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@DavidVorick I once generated this table to extract bits from a Von multi-state Neumann extractor for dice: https://t.co/MVppczFnkY

Unfortunately I think I've lost the code to generate it.

@danrobinson @IamNomad @Tetranode Nothing in Bitcoin Script is turing complete, and BIP342 (tapscript) doesn't change that.

Miniscript is just a framework for reasoning/constructing/analyzing a particular subset of Bitcoin Script. It doesn't change or add any semantics - that'd need a consensus rule change.

The only problem is that the codesigning tool on MacOS doesn't do the *exact* same thing as the opensource one which we use to attach the signature to the binary inside the Linux-based build environment.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@IEM_WLL @_jonasschnelli_ @achow101 The problem is that both in the 2nd and the 3rd phase the codesign_allocate tool is used; once as part of the actual codesigning, and once to make space for attaching the published signature.

The latter one runs in Linux however, using the opensource version of the tool.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@IEM_WLL @_jonasschnelli_ @achow101 So the build process has 3 stages:
* (anyone) run the build process without signing; publish the hashes they get
* (the key owner) runs the MacOS codesign tool to convert it into a signed binary, extracts the signature and publishes it.
* (anyone) attaches the signature to binary

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @IEM_WLL @_jonasschnelli_ @achow101 This is just to shut up the OS from complaining about it being a binary from an untrusted source. Ideally we'd have a way to construct these in a distributed fashion like the rest of the build process, but unfortunately, it right now requires one person with a private key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @IEM_WLL @_jonasschnelli_ @achow101 It makes space in the executable file to place the codesigning signature. The codesigning tool uses this; first making space for the signature, then signing the space-made but unsigned version of the binary, and then placing the signature in that space.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Due to timezone differences it wasn't actually night for me.

Lessons learned:
* Apple's codesign_allocate tool rounds x86_64 segments to 0x2000 bytes, while the published source code does to 0x1000.
* Binaries contain a list of hashes (one per page), and sign that.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @qertoip @stephanlivera such steal, wow

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@jmcorgan @stephanlivera I think there is a enormous difference between having money controlled by third party, and not having any at all. I'd still prefer to control it myself of course.

If I was somehow unable to use BTC, I think i'd prefer having USD in a bank account than not having it at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@jmcorgan @stephanlivera That's absolutely true, but it's true for everything. In my view, the notion of ownership has nothing to do with the ability to enforce it.

Bitcoin is unique that it's possible to enforce it yourself. That doesn't make it not yours if you don't do that.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jmcorgan @stephanlivera It is a legal concept, but it's also a social construct. I believe that a concept of ownership exists without the existence of a legal framework to enforce it (e.g. kids feel like their things are theirs, even if guardians have a legal right to confiscate it).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_benkaufman @stephanlivera That's an interesting point.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_benkaufman @stephanlivera Why not? If you give control of your BTC to a private business, they're still yours in my view. It may be an irresponsible decision for you to do so, but if the business spends your coins without permission, that's still theft.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@stephanlivera Bitcoin is unique in that it's a liquid asset for which it's finally feasible to have control in the hands of end-user owners, but that doesn't make them the same.

That ability is something to encourage, but I think equating it with ownership itself is confusing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stephanlivera Ownership and control are not the same thing. I don't even mean that in a legal sense - I'd be very surprised if many people think of control for anything being very related to ownership at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@stephanlivera Controversial opinion: yes.

If you give your pet to a friend to take care of while traveling, is the pet not yours anymore? No.

What if it was a business that does the same? Still no.

What if it was a physical bitcoin instead of a pet? I'd still say no.

And ideally, we find a formula that works for every number. Making sure that it holds for at least as many we can test is a first step.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: For that purpose this better bound doesn't actually help. The algorithm performs 62 (on 64-bit) or 30 (on 32-bit) steps at once, and for neither does reducing the iteration count from 741 (paper formula) to 724 (this work) matter. It's still 12 resp. 25 batches of steps.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Our practical interest in this is of course using this algorithm in the libsecp256k1 library, which currently uses a (fairly naive) exponentiation ladder to compute modular inverses. Peter Dettman (and others) have been working on a PR: https://t.co/CVwZt438kX

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
To actually do this analysis, Greg Maxwell and I verified it for all numbers up to 6606 bits in size, because, well... we could - he had some decent hardware available: https://t.co/WXD3KMIwfW

The computation is O(n^4) or so, and memory is O(n^3), so going further is hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: It doesn't give a nice provable formula, but it is possible to run this analysis computationally for pretty large numbers, and from that data a formula can be extracted - which appears to be asymptotically around 1.9% lower than the paper's (generally proven) formula.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: That bound is essential for performance - the better the bound, the faster the algorithm. I looked for other approaches to find these bounds, and found that by reasoning over convex hulls of potential variables during execution it's possible to find a bound for specific inputs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: It's an intriguing (and fast) algorithm for computing GCDs and modular inverses. To make it constant time (as is desirable in cryptographic applications) an upper bound on the number of algorithm steps needs to be known.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@AnonOnAMoose Making sure that the checksum on addresses for future segwit versions in Bitcoin (and other things that choose to use the updated bech32 encoding) detect most errors people might make.

We ran a ton of numbers, and found something decent.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt And honestly, I'm rather surprised that the final constant that gets XOR'ed into the checksum has such an effect, and can be leveraged to provide pretty substantial properties for insertion/deletion errors as well.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt That was an oversight of course. Bech32 was only specifically designed for protection against substitution errors (as that could be done algebraically), but the assumption was that it'd behave fairly good in general against other types of mutations.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt As it was discovered that the result has a fairly serious weakness (insertion in penultimate position has 2^-10 chance of acceptance), we set out to find a tweak that improves upon this. But it's just a tweak to provide a property the code was originally not at all designed for.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt Also, all codes tend to have "random" properties that go beyond the ones they were constructed for. Bech32 was constructed in a way that guarantees 3 substitutions, but among the possibilities, one was selected that actually guaranteed 4 (and sometimes 5).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@renepickhardt Well there are obviously ways of constructing error detecting codes with guaranteed properties, without the need for exhaustive analysis of any kind.

I don't know of ways to guarantee insertions/deletions detection that result in efficient codes, though.

name: Pieter Wuille

It's keeping almost all of bech32 - just changing the final constant that gets XOR'ed in.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@JuergenStrobel @jratcliff @BobMcElrath @Ethan_Heilman Well, sure - but there aren't any particular gotchas around non-member functions.

Global mutable variables (and mutable member static variables) represent global state, could introduce race conditions, have initialization order worries, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jratcliff @BobMcElrath @Ethan_Heilman Unsure if this was clear, but in this context I was talking about non-const static member variables. Nothing wrong with static member functions, or static constants - but mutable static variables are really just globals that try to hide their globalness.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @Ethan_Heilman I think in general non-const static members are confusing. Their actual behavior is clearer if you just make them a global variable outside the class (or even better, avoid a global/static member entirely).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @BobMcElrath But this deduplication is only possible because a constructor is code, and thus inherently read-only. For read-write linker symbols, you can't deduplicate.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman I don't have an explanation for why this rule even holds for classes defined in anonymous namespaces, as the problem of it existing in multiple compilation units doesn't exist there.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Ethan_Heilman As the class definition could end up in multiple modules, there wouldn't be a clear one to hold the initialization code.

Similar to how you can declare a global variable in multiple modules, but its definition/initialization can only be in one place.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman My guess: static member variables are essentially globals in terms of lifetime, but there must be one piece of code that is responsible for initializing them. There is no constructor it can be tied to (like non-static ones), so it's tied to the module that holds the definition.

fin/

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@benthecarman @RubinhoISR So maybe a TL;DR: anytime you feel "hmm, wouldn't it be nice if we could add fields to transaction inputs?", an annex is probably approximately what you want.

Note that no details about this have been worked out, and maybe we'll never even them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR Another possibility is something like BIP115 (OP_CHECKBLOCKATHEIGHT) which is somewhat more elegant as an annex - it doesn't interact with spending conditions at all, and shouldn't be part of script. It's more something like an extra "nlocktime", but a block-hash based one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR Those inputs cannot be spent simultaneously in the same transaction. If instead there were a per-input locktime, and the tx-wide rule would be that all of them need to be satisfied, you could have an OP_CLTV that just asserts the per-input one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR That's not the only example of an annex though. Another example is for example per-input locktimes. Currently the nLockTime/OP_CLTV mechanism only supports one locktime per tx. What if one input requires a time-based locktime, and another requires a height-based one?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR So the idea would be that (in such a hypothetical case), the tx "weight" becomes defined as (actual weight as defined now) + (200 WU)*num_fancyops_executed, and by adding an annex, you can signal this number without needing to execute it first.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@benthecarman @RubinhoISR Who knows. New cryptography is something you'd probably want through something else than Taproot, otherwise you're inherently restricted to its ECDLP assumption.

Other examples are just things like hashing more data, bigger stack operations, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR ... which would be a very twisted incentive that we want to avoid. The idea with the annex is that a txin could just get a marker that says "this input does 11 fancyops", which can be observed without actually execution, and thus can be counted towards the tx "size" instead.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR But what if somehow an opcode is proposed that generally only needs a few WU in the witness, but is much more computationally expensive than checksig? If we'd want to use the same framework, and say 200 WU per such opcode... then spenders may be forced to add junk to the witness.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR Having a limit of 1 checksig per 50 WU witness isn't a problem for useful scripts, as every checksig will consume at least a pubkey and a signature, together already 98 WU anyway.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @RubinhoISR That avoids the complex optimization problem for miners that exists in theory today (actual implementations just ignore it, though). Ideally they'd try to both maximize fee per weight and fee per sigop - this much harder to do (and estimate) than just one metric.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@benthecarman @RubinhoISR The motivating example is hypothetical opcodes that are more expensive per byte than signature checking.

BIP342 replaces the sigops limit with a resource cost: everything is translated to bytes that you "pay" for. If a script executes N checksigs, it needs 50*N witness bytes.

name: Pieter Wuille

@spacecadetready The polynomials (with all coefficients) are:
* 6*x^0 + 7*x^1 + 0*x^2 + 1*x^3
* 1*x^0 + 0*x^1 + 7*x^2 + 6*x^6

The 0 coefficient moves degree when reversing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @spacecadetready There is no missing ^2 power. Read my tweet above again :)

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @spacecadetready Yes. The coefficients of the first polynomial (from low to high degree) are [6, 7, 0, 1]. The second one has [1, 0, 7, 6].

tweet: @galois1900 In the context of where I encountered this - polynomials over GF(2^n) - reversing a list if definitely faster than computing inverses.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Neat trick: if you want to compute the inverses of the roots of a polynomial, just reverse the order of its coefficients before solving.

E.g. (inverses of roots of x^3 - 7*x + 6) = (roots of 6*x^3 - 7*x^2 + 1).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@giacomozucco @peterktodd This isn't replacing the hash function. It's replacing the concatenation *before hashing* with addition. And it's a bad idea as it reduces security.

What works is replacing concatenation with sorting + concatenating. That's obviously (slightly) harder, but hides position.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@peterktodd Note that it only completely hides the original position in case only one leaf is revealed. When multiple leaves are revealed, you may still leak something.

E.g. (A,B,C,D) and (A,C,B,D) never hash to the same thing. Normalizing by sorting the leaves before hashing is better.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kallerosenbaum One of PGP's issues is the fact that the claimed identities are "name / email / comment" strings, rather than specific assertions. E.g. it'd be great to have separate identities for "known online as", "owner of ICQ# x", "has government-X issued photo id with name Y".

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath https://t.co/YYRNt3wgQS suggests that logarithmic return is what I'm talking about actually: logreturn = log(new/old) = log(new) - log(old).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BobMcElrath Seems like combining the worst of both worlds (complexity from the logarithm, and nonlinear under composition).

What unit problems do you mean? You can also say neper = log(new/old), so it's a dimensionless unit.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Zach_of_Earth Glad someone actually finds it controversial.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Any logarithmic unit has this linearity under composition, but using a natural logarithm (as opposed to a 10-based one like (deci)bell) means that for small percentages, the number just matches: 1 microneper = multiplication by 1.0010005.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Controversial opinion: we should use neper as unit for relative growth.

neper = log(new_value) - log(old_value)

1% growth = ~0.01 neper
10% growth = ~0.095 neper
doubling = ~0.69 neper

10% growth + 10% growth = 21%(!) growth = 0.095+0.095 neper = 0.19 neper.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney Before Bitcoin v0.3.6, an opcode OP_VER existed. It pushed the version number of the verifier onto the stack. Any use of scripts observing that number would have caused a fork, one per release.

VER caused every release until mid-2010 to be a hard-forking change.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @anant_tap Any reason why the 2-round signing approach can't work? This means every signer must act twice, with a coordination step in between. It is far easier to implement safely (but still not without pitfalls) than the non-interactive signing one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @anant_tap A malicious coordinate (or other signer) at best can result in just no valid signature being produced in the end. It shouldn't ever result in a signature for the wrong thing, or leaking your private key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @anant_tap No, they'd verify if they agree with the message before signing. If you don't do that, what's the point of a multisig-like policy in the first place?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap I'm talking about the signature scheme in abstract here.

The message is just whatever is being signed. In the context of Bitcoin transactions that is the transaction sighash - and in order for the signer to understand what they're signing extra info like PSBT may be useful.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap The signers verify that (1) they like the message (2) they have never ever produced a partial signature with nonce number N.

Then they sign knowing the public nonces of all other signers at position N, using their own private + private nonce number N.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap Concretely to use this, you need to have pre-agreed sets of signers. Each signer produces a bunch of secret nonces (say 1000), and shares them with the other parties.

At sign time, a coordinator asks all "plz sign message m if you agree, with nonce number N".

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap It doesn't even need to be secure - the partial signatures produced don't leak anything, and can be verified for correctness before use.

But obviously some means of communication out of band must exist to construct the signature - interactive or not.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap > Does it take care of the change address verification as well while signing?

That's entirely unrelated. If signers want to verify that before agreeing to sign, yes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @anant_tap It certainly involves passing *something* around still, which may be PSBTs. Non-interactive in this context means that every signer only acts once; something still has to bring all the responses together and construct a real signature. That something doesn't need private keys.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@anant_tap > Pass PSBTs around

That's hard to say. This precomputed nonce approach is pretty specialized, with extra pitfalls. I don't expect it to be used in any standardized setting - only inside protocols that can strictly control things.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@mflaxman There are some advantages to BIP341/342 even for situations where interactive signing can't be used, such as not needing to reveal the full script/keys, and the fact that all input amounts/scriptPubKeys are signed.

But sure, this will all take time.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @mflaxman I think interactive signing will mostly be used for situations where the keys are online.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@jeffburdges It is! Though the non-AGM proof suffers from the same 1/4th reduction as other ROM/DL MuSig proofs (worse than the 1/2 reduction in Schnorr), and the 5 nonces (if you take the linear dependency problem into account) are awkward.

The AGM proof is tight, and only needs 2 nonces.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jeffburdges Moving the nonce agreement to setup definitely has complications and risks (your nonce has to be stored securely, your knowledge of other nonces has to be tamperproof), and not always advisable. But if you need very fast signing, it is at least possible under those conditions.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @jfnewbery ooooooOOOOOOOOOOOO

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @real_or_random Thanks, I forget that there is still more cool stuff coming :)

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: It relies on a technique where every participant provides more than one nonce, variants of which have been independently discovered in https://t.co/ig8bb7yBH3 (@chelseakomlo, Ian Goldberg) and https://t.co/J6CmSjG6EZ (Handan Kilinc Alper, @jeffburdges).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Private nesting means this: you can have multiple levels of aggregation, e.g. M=MuSig(A,B,C) P=MuSig(M,D,E). In this case, the signing can be performed without D and E being aware that M in fact consists of multiple participants itself.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The precomputation of the first round means you effectively have two choices:
* Non-interactive setup (where address is computed from pubkeys) but signing needs interaction.
* A setup where the signers pregenerate & exchange nonces, but signing is noninteractive.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It comes at the cost of one extra EC multiplication at signing time, and slightly stronger security assumptions (the paper gives a proof in ROM+OMDL and one with better bounds in ROM+AGM+OMDL).

It doesn't support stateless signing like MuSig-DN, but also doesn't have its costs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
This paper by @real_or_random, @n1ckler, and Yannick Seurin is what I've been hinting at a few times already:

* Aggregation identical to MuSig, but only needs 2 signing rounds
* First round can be precomputed, permitting non-interactive signing
* Supports privately nested MuSig

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Mario_Gibney I agree, at least if you interpret it as "The value something would have if it wasn't used as a store of value or for speculation" or so. Who knows what the world would be like in such a hypothetical?

Still, I'd say BTC is a rare example of something having intrinsic value 0.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C In case the total number C of spending combinations isn't too large (say, up to millions), they can be split out into C branches of a tree, where each leaf is one script corresponding to just one combination.

This means that at spending time not the entire script is revealed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C Whenever the key path isn't available (because the signers don't support aggregation, or because native thresholds weren't used and some other set of signers than the one in the key path spend), there are no benefits from Taproot per se, but there are from the Merkle tree.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C With even more sophisticated signers, and more complicated address generation, it's also possible to use native threshold signature schemes for the key path.

That would allow K-of-N to *always* spend with a single signature and nothing more. There are many pitfalls here, though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benthecarman @BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C Yes, MuSig-DN isn't very practical due to its signing complexity of around 1s CPU time. It's a cool idea, and even nicer that it could be proven. It may also be the right solution in some conditions, but probably not very many.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C Because then a protocol is needed for multiple parties to jointly construct a signature, like MuSig (though a paper should be out in the next few days that simplifies this significantly in some cases).

Still, whenever this can be used, it's not restricted to just N-of-N.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C This is obviously the case for all single-key conditions. It's also the case for a 1-of-N multisig, where the most likely signer is used as key path, and they're the one to sign.

It gets more interesting with combinations of keys. This is harder for the signers.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinOnly_IN @khannib @benthecarman @nic__carter @coinmetrics @0xB10C It's complicated.

The biggest gain in "policy privacy" is when the key path can be used. In Taproot, one (combination of) key(s) is privileged at address time creation, and that key can spend the coins with just a signature, not even revealing that other conditions existed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:

Bitcoin's P2P protocol has forever supported gossipping. It's how transactions and IP addresses propagate on the network. BIP155 only makes an improvement to that so that TorV3 addresses can be sent too.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt @th_s4m0ht @fredhrson @zeroknowledgefm I agree with @renepickhardt that the details of the optimization itself are more for a blackboard session than for a podcast.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@renepickhardt @th_s4m0ht @fredhrson @zeroknowledgefm For compatible curves, numbers lambda and beta exist such that lambda*(x,y) = (beta*x,y).

Pick f(P)=lambda*P, and n1/n2 such that n1+lambda*n2=n, and both are only 128 bits. There is a known simple algorithm for finding those.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@renepickhardt @th_s4m0ht @fredhrson @zeroknowledgefm This transformation works in general (just pick f(P)=2^128*P, and select n1 and n2 as the lower/higher half of n).

It's only interesting if an f exists that can be efficiently computed. The GLV optimization is one way of doing so, and secp256k1 is chosen to permit it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt @th_s4m0ht @fredhrson @zeroknowledgefm The very short explanation is that when trying to compute n*P (with n a 256-bit scalar and P a point on a curve), it can be rewritten as n1*P + n2*f(P), where both n1 and n2 are only 128 bits. This means the multiplication now only needs 128 doublings instead of 256.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@afilini @Elichai2 @jb55 To be clear: my question was mostly rhetorical. I was trying to convey how hard it is to have assurances about software if you can't even assume that memcmp behaves correctly.

Now that it's known, it's easy to add tests/workarounds for this exact easy. But what about unknowns?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman I concur.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@afilini I believe it's pretty deterministic, so we'll certainly write an explicit test for it (and then enable -fno-builtin-memcmp, or otherwise avoid the cases where it happens).

My concern is more: how could we have made sure that something *like* this is caught?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
1) It also affects functions that indirectly compile to memcmp (e.g. std::lexicographic_compare in C++).
2) It seems -fno-builtin-memcmp fixes it.
3) It seems "memcmp(...) <= 0" is not affected, while "memcmp(...) < 0" can be.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Some GCC 9 & 10 have a known issue where (builtin) memcmp is sometimes miscompiled when one argument is a constant array that contains zero bytes.

How can you have a process that gives assurances for correct software in the presence of that?

https://t.co/7HpEeQf5F3

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 SHA256 on 32-bit ARM systems is (relative to other operations) probably more than an order of magnitude slower than it is on high-end x86 with SHA-NI hardware acceleration.

So you can't really set a "price" for that. But you can set a limit that makes the worst case reasonable.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 I actually investigated what the worst CPU/byte of various opcodes is, and when taking BIP342 "1 checksig per 50 bytes of witness data" into account, they're all within an order of magnitude from each other (which is probably the best we can aim for without platform specifics).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 This was partially addressed with segwit, which reduced the relative cost of inputs but not of outputs, but it's not perfect.

Taproot also creates a CPU usage metric, and requires that the script's "size" pay for that, setting a maximum CPU/byte limit. New opcodes can use that.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 That works well for some resources (bandwidth, storage, and to a lesser extent CPU usage).

It's very hard for others, like UTXO set space consumption, as it depends on how long it was left unspent. Charging up front and deleting if not spent creates very strange incentives.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 It's a complicated topic.

I don't think we should think about it as charging an accurate cost for every type of usage. Its purpose is to limit the worst-case impact a block can have on the network.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@FelixWeis @BitcoinErrorLog I wasn't assuming standard or typical transactions.

The maximum number of UTXO ops per block is using a block with 1 tx, 1 input, and 111096 outputs. That number didn't change with segwit.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinErrorLog I don't see what this has to do with Bitcoin Core.

We made a proposal, first as a talk, with hundreds watching, then as a BIPs. Both made it clear that capacity was increased. After long discussion, the proposal was accepted.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BitcoinErrorLog BIP141

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BitcoinErrorLog One of the goals was the malleability fix.
Another goal was script versioning.
Yet another goal was increasing capacity.

Segwit enabled all of them, and importantly, without the costs of just multiplying all resource costs by N.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 @TheBlueMatt @TheBlueMatt So I'm pretty sure that this can be broken with 2^65 EC additions, and sorting two lists of 2^64 points each... 180000 years of CPU time, and 500 exabytes of storage, by naive calculation.

I wouldn't be surprised if there are better ways.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 @TheBlueMatt I think this works.

Split known xor C into C0, C1 (low and high 64 bits).
f_i(v) = (2^128*v + (C_i xor v))*2^(64*i)*G
S_i = [f_i(v) for v in range(2^64)]

Every point with DL such that high xor low = C can now be written as the sum of one element in S0 and one in S1.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 @TheBlueMatt Actually, can BSGS work? You'd need to split the 2^128 sized range [x] + [x xor C] (which has low xor high = C) into two subsets of size 2^64 such that every full element is the sum of one elements in each subset. Given the incompatibility between + and xor, that seems hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 @TheBlueMatt Not sure if you can adapt Pollard's Rho to work with a known range - you'd need a way for the individual steps to stay within that range, despite starting at a random DL. Would be nice though as it's O(1) memory.

Baby Step Giant Step should work fine, but needs O(sqrt n) memory.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dmpsim @sanket1729 @Blockstream @adam3us This is similar to malleability. Miniscript's type system lets you reason about potential malleability of scripts, and the current compilers are restricted to non-malleable outputs. But a signer could choose to not enforce that, as you'd still want to be able to spend.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@dmpsim @sanket1729 @Blockstream @adam3us Miniscript is really a framework for reasoning about scripts, not a tool. That framework will expose a way to detect mixed height/time usage.

The policy compiler(s) are one thing built using it, as are generic signing implementations. Those can expose as warnings, or not.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @sanket1729 @_drgo @hodlwave @MartyBent @matt_odell @adam3us @notgrubles @ffstls Note that Erlay is about transaction relay, not historical block chain synchronization. The latter is just once per node.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@sanket1729 @_drgo @hodlwave @MartyBent @matt_odell @adam3us @notgrubles @ffstls Per node bandwidth scales with O(connections_per_node), so globally that's O(nodes*conn_per_node). If the number of outgoing connections per node is bounded by a constant, that's also just O(nodes).

Erlay keeps it (mostly) at O(nodes) even with non-const connections.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MadarsV @badcryptobitch @n1ckler @real_or_random Yes, and to a number of other things too. Users could go put all their funds in salted OP_TRUE outputs too, and it may even work until miners attack it.

As said, I don't think this is an absolute reason to never change assumptions - but it should be a consideration.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @badcryptobitch @n1ckler @real_or_random You could argue for opt-in support for new cryptography, but it's not even that simple. If you don't trust $FANCYCRYPTO, and a major part of the ecosystem starts using it, but you don't, the value of your coins may still be affected if a break threatens a % of the total supply.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@badcryptobitch @n1ckler @real_or_random I don't think that's an absolute, and at some point I expect that Bitcoin will adopt new cryptography (e.g. pairing), but it's a change that needs very careful considerations.

And there is plenty to do and gain from just EC based constructions.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@badcryptobitch @n1ckler @real_or_random As for why Schnorr signatures and not BLS as a proposal for Bitcoin: because they don't change the system's security assumptions compared to the ECDSA that is already in use.

BLS requires a new curve, and one with additional (pairing) assumptions over just secp256k1 EC.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @badcryptobitch @n1ckler @real_or_random MuSig (and MuSig-DN) produce signatures that are indistinguishable at verification time from regular Schnorr signatures, meaning they're compatible with the proposed BIP340 standard in Bitcoin. Using a different scheme would require additional support in consensus rules.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet:
There should be a blog post soon, but the PRF and code for its arithmetic circuit can be found on https://t.co/f75Y6DIlkE.

My coauthors @n1ckler, @real_or_random, and Yannick Seurin are also working on a more practical (stateful) approach that enables 2-round signing without ZKP

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: With a signing time around 1s CPU time, it's a high price to pay just to get rid of stateful signing sessions and a signing round (the approach also only needs 2 rounds rather than 3), but in some cases (e.g. procedures where signing involves going into a vault), perhaps.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It however also means that it's possible to do Schnorr multisignature signing in a completely stateless way (e.g. a hardware device that needs no memory of what rounds/sessions it has participated it), and without RNG.

I found it interesting to see what was needed to prove this.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Problem: can't use derandomized nonces in Schnorr multisignatures.

Solution: do it anyway, and use a ZKP to prove you did it right. It's rather inefficient, and not surprising on its own.

The paper also describes a provably secure EC-based PRF with low arithmetic gate count.

name: Pieter Wuille

(also, the proofs can be made deterministic, but not provably deterministic without yet another proof on top...).

tweet: @bashnewid It's harmless, as those apparent IP addresses can't actually be used (for now), so it's not like anything is affected by it. Still, it's funny to see such prehistoric relics in the codebase (well-documented though!).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bashnewid ELI15: a very old version of Bitcoin Core (before it was called that way) would sometimes send out garbage, that could be misinterpreted as a bogus IP address. There is still code to explicitly ignore those, even though the bug was fixed a decade ago.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
I just realized while reviewing a PR that Bitcoin Core still has code to ignore IP addresses in IPv6 range ::ff:ff00:0:0:0/72 because those were accidentally constructed due to a bug in version <=0.2.8 of the codebase (May 2010).

Harmless, as it's in reserved range 0::/8 anyway.

tweet: @8ArmedOctopus I'm ok.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: In which I go into some of the practical problems and unexpected pitfalls when trying to use Schnorr multisignatures and related things in production...

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@peterktodd @theinstagibbs Or you wanted to use BIP32 derived keys for convenience in combination with Schnorr signatures?

If the message doesn't commit to the public keys, this means an attacker can take a signature for one key, and mutate it into a valid signature for another key with the same xpub.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@peterktodd @theinstagibbs Or perhaps you want to use deterministic nonces - well known to make Schnorr-like signature schemes less prone to pitfalls - in combination with multisignatures.

Done naively, again, this is completely broken. Your cosigners can learn your private key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@peterktodd @theinstagibbs Want to extend this to threshold schemes? Another "solved problem".

Until recently, as far as I know, all work on efficient schemes with provable properties required a threshold of less than 50% signers - while most practical applications want a majority signing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@peterktodd @theinstagibbs With that solved, you may think that it's trivial to do this recursively - construct a multisig between say a PC and a hardware wallet, and then use that multisig as a participant in a 2-of-3 with other people to secure company funds.

Think again - done naively this is broken.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @peterktodd @theinstagibbs For example, MuSig solves a superficially unimportant, but practically very relevant problem: being able to construct a single key that requires multiple parties to agree *from just pubkeys*. Without you might need access to cold keys to even construct the multisig address.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @peterktodd @theinstagibbs However, you're right that making just multisignatures (and even more so, threshold signatures) encountered a lot of practical problems, some of which were (theoretical) solutions found for.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @peterktodd @theinstagibbs Russell's attack is on a specific way of building an aggregate signature scheme out of a Schnorr-like multisig scheme, suggested in a paper from 2006. As far as I know, this isn't implemented in any production system. It's not an issue with Schnorr (multi)signatures directly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@hasufl However, that does NOT mean that softforks are automatically a good idea, or safe, even to those who don't use its features.

Reckless activation can threaten chain convergeance. Insecure spending rules could hurt trust in the currency's value (if widely used). They can censor.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl So, if you accept these longer term effects, I think that no, softforks are opt-in, and there is nothing special about segwit in this regard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl Following wide ecosystem adoption, and the lack of maintained software that does not implement the softfork that follows it, I think you can argue that effectively little choice remains to not "opt into" a softfork, but that's a second order effect, and independent of rule change

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl However, that is already the case if people use silly/insecure scripts, and isn't made any worse by softforks.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl You can argue that there could be apparent anyonecanspend outputs in the history of coins you receive as a non-upgraded user, which impacts the ability for those coins to be reorganized if their validation isn't thoroughly verified.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hasufl However, the fact that there are rules out there that some nodes are implementing but you don't per se I think is a non-issue: clearly you also don't care about these rules. If you start using wallet software that relies on them you will, and you'll use a node that does.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@hasufl That's true for literally every softfork I think: nodes enforce new rules you're not aware of, and thus there could be invalid transactions included in the chain that you can't detect.

During the adoption phase there is a security impact: the lowered guarantee for convergance.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BashCo_ Though, arguably, you could choose to not include the coinbase outputs of the past 100 blocks, as they aren't yet mature (and thus can't be moved).

The gettxoutsetinfo number does not take that into account.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BashCo_ ... which I believe in the current era to be 14437456.25+6.25*height (constant calculated as 50*209999 + 25*210000 + 12.5*210000 - 629999*6.25; only 209999 times 50 because genesis coinbase output is unspendable).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @GeistLight @BashCo_ No, there is one more thing excluded: overwritten coinbases (see BIP30, and later BIP34).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BashCo_ Summing the expected value of coinbases is trivial, it's just 210000 * (50 BTC + 25 BTC + 12.5 BTC) + num_blocks_of_6.25_BTC * 6.25 BTC, which is a simple function of the height.

The number varying between nodes would just mean they use different UTXO set implementations.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BashCo_ Ultimately, the exact supply is unknown: nobody knows how many coins have been lost, or will for other reasons never reenter circulation.

Bitcoin's goal is to have an auditable, bounded, fixed supply schedule, and that's what we should - and can - verify.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BashCo_ The reported number is ~arbitrary: it excludes OP_RETURN outputs, but there are other scripts that could be determined to be unspendable and removed as well.

You should celebrate that it's below the sum of the coinbases, not the exact number matching.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dmaddock1 "Bitcoin developer admits smart contracts are getting harder to write."

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@hhuey8 Or perhaps put otherwise, avoiding the semantics discussion of what a smart contract is:

Doing anything interesting with Script requires designing an application and protocols to construct and spend them. That is - so far - far more work than coming up with the Script involved.

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: I'm intentionally not mentioning specific projects here, as my criticism is not directed at the (great) work they're doing - only at the way it tends to be reported.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
There is interesting work, including some of the work I contributed to with the Miniscript policy compiler, that helps with that part. It's useful, but it's not revolutionary, and in my opinion, also not nearly the most relevant part.

Making Script usable will take a lot of work

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Dear reporters,

Stop writing that "Bitcoin smart contracts are getting easier to write". No, they're not even things you write.

Smart contracts are multiparty protocols that require extensive design. One tiny part of that is constructing the actual Script(s) used.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tonyadamsmsf @nntaleb He's asking about the expected longest run.

For any given set of 250 coin tosses, there is around:
* 1.46% chance of length 5,
* 11.8% length 6
* 24.2% length 7
* 24.3% length 8
* 17.1% length 9
* 10.0% length 10
* 5.45% length 11
* ...

Expected (=avg) of those is 8.29886723896

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @tierotiero @MartyBent @sanket1729 I sincerely hope it will!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @tierotiero @MartyBent @sanket1729 My belief is that this isn't because policy compilation was bad; only that there are so few cases where someone actually had the opportunity and need for designing a custom script that the "market" for compilation is tiny.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @tierotiero @MartyBent @sanket1729 Sorry if this wasn't clear. I'm not saying policy compilation is useless, or that improvements to it are - only that it isn't novel, and that despite existing in various forms for a while already, it has barely seen any practical use.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tierotiero @shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 Does that matter? If it was useful, it'd be useful still.

I think the issue isn't how good it is or was - it's that "Script programming" isn't a standalone thing. It's part of developing interactive protocols, and without the ability to integrate it's mostly useless.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 That's what sets Miniscript apart - you don't *need* the policy compilation. You can do useful stuff with (within some bounds) arbitrarily composed scripts, without even needing to explain to anyone what it does or how it was constructed. They can tell by themselves.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 Of course, it's the most tangible result: look a website, you say what you want, and it compiles to script!

But it's not new - for example Ivy existed too. I think the interesting part is the ability to write generic signers, and wallets that watch generic things, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 No, but I do think it would be better if there was more interest and focus on integration of Miniscript than there is on its policy compilation. To me, that part is just a demo of what generic script reasoning can do - but in the media it seems like it's only thing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 </rant>

To be clear: I'm super happy to see developments in this regard, and absolutely don't want to discourage anything.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 If that exists, it will actually be useful to have good policy compilers, so that these compositions can be done automatically and safely.

But before that point, Scripts are really a thing that application developers decide one once at design time.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 One day I hope you can have a Lightning wallet whose funds are secured by a Green-like 2FA setup, which includes a hardware wallet - and its transactions can be coinjoined, where all of these things have no clue what any of the others are doing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 There is a lot of work to be done there, and policy compilation is one aspect of that - but also things like PSBT, descriptors, Miniscript's signing/analysis framework, ..., and actually getting those integrated in wallet software and other applications.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shesek @MartyBent @sanket1729 I'd like to point out that the ability to write policies in higher-level languages is great, but it's only a very small aspect in making them actually usable.

It's not like you can plug in the output of a compiler into any wallet or other program and do anything useful.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Elichai2 @LLFOURN As I mentioned elsewhere, however, just knowing that distribution is presumably infeasible.

So while we know that the distribution is very non-uniform, a polynomial-time attacker can't actually use that distinction.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@LLFOURN @Elichai2 It's not!

What I said holds statistically, but not computationally. It requires knowing what the distribution of SHA256({0,1}^256) is, and that on itself is presumably intractable.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Elichai2 @LLFOURN Just treat every individual output as binomially distributed with p=2^-256 and n=2^256 (throw 2^256 balls to 2^256 buckets, uniformly). You'd conclude that around 1/e (36.8%) of the buckets are empty.

So if you find any input that produces such an output, you distinguished.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LLFOURN @Elichai2 I probably shouldn't have said SHA256, but "some ideal 256-bit hash function", as we don't actually know that its distribution isn't accidentally much better than expected from a random function.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@LLFOURN @Elichai2 I was recently surprised by this: if you look at the distribution of outputs of say SHA256 restricted to 256-bit inputs, you get something enormously non-uniform.

With an oracle that counts SHA256 preimages in {0,1}^256, it only takes a few queries to distinguish from random.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dannydiekroeger There is additional confusion here, because before the introduction of P2SH, "address" and "key identifier" were kind of synonyms; every address corresponded to exactly one key. This is why you'll see blockexplorers present P2PK outputs as their corresponding P2PKH addresses.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dannydiekroeger Mining code in early days used to mine to P2PK outputs. Since it was generated by the miner itself, there was no need for that output to be representable as an address, and P2PK was very simple. P2PK was also used in pay-to-IP, for similar reason: no need for an address.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dannydiekroeger However, there is no requirement that a transaction output has an associated address. It's a freeform script, and in theory, lots of types of scripts can be valid. Historically, the most common non-address outputs were P2PK and bare multisig.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dannydiekroeger They are - kind of. This definition probably shifted over time, but now, an address is understood to be a shorthand human readable notation for a particular script. The defined address types are P2PKH (1...), P2SH (3...), BIP173 (bc1...; for witness outputs, incl. P2WSH/P2WPKH).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dannydiekroeger This is not actually true. Bitcoin v0.1.0 came with support for P2PKH addresses already. There has never been an address format for P2PK, except indirectly through pay-to-IP (where the address literally was just an IP address, which your wallet would ask how to pay to).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LLFOURN @_prestwich Though, if there is some post-taproot v2 witness version, ideally it reuses the same annex semantics.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LLFOURN @_prestwich Yep, exactly. And all we needed to enable that (at some point, possibly never) is now reserving some recognizable space for data that isn't given another meaning, and is committed to by signatures (to prevent witness-stuffing malleability).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @LLFOURN @_prestwich The downside is that, in general, you can't tell what is even an opcode and what is data without access to the scriptPubKey being spent. So you wouldn't be able to determine the feerate of a standalone transaction; you'd need the UTXOs it's spending as well.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ajtowns @_prestwich I haven't thought too hard about this example. What would be the issue you see?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @mindspillage It is proportional to how long before the deadline you start.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich The annex is recognizable without context, mostly by exploiting a thankful coincidence about what set of witnesses is valid for v0 (first byte of last witness stack item can only take on certain byte values).

This, I think, can't be accomplished with a new leaf version.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich Instead, it would be nice if there could just be a marker on the input that says "increment the apparent weight (and corresponding op budget) by N", without taking N bytes.

Logistically, it would be annoying if that marker can only be parsed when the spent output is available.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich The motivating example for the annex is this.

Imagine a new opcode is added that needs few bytes but has high CPU cost. You'd want a high weight budget per such opcode, but that may require actually stuffing the witness with dummy data just to get the necessary budget.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich Not sure what you mean.

What I mean is that I believe that annex can't be used to introduce new script conditions. A new leaf version could introduce its own annex-like thing, but that wouldn't be able to apply to old leaf versions.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich So is there something an annex can do that a new leaf version can't? I think they're orthogonal.

For example, a feature where you could restrict a tx to only be valid in a chain that contains a certain block hash. It can't be done with a leaf version, as it's a sign-time thing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: I don't know if we ever made a comprehensive list of all the upgrade mechanisms in BIP341/342 and why they exist.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_prestwich As the annex isn't committed to by the scriptPubKey, it's more a way to extend witness possibilities than it is directly a way to add new semantics.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_prestwich Leaf versions were really only added because we had a few bits to spare in the control block, and it seemed wasteful to reserve them. They're mostly a convenience, I think, as OP_SUCCESSx can achieve the same (add an OP_V2 e.g.).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@_prestwich * Leaf versions: for revamping script semantics
* OP_SUCCESSx: for new opcodes, without coordinating new version
* Pubkey types: for new sighash flags/cryptography without needing an explosion of new opcodes.
* Annex: for effectively adding new fields like nLockTime

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_prestwich I believe that list is exhaustive. See https://t.co/wXc5uU3IpL.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@San_person @wtogami @orionwl All full blocks you have are always available for relay. The problem is letting potential peers thar want to download them know you have them.

BIP159 only has one level: do you support relaying the last 144 blocks before the tip or not. Even maximally pruned nodes keep that many

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@theinstagibbs @wtogami @orionwl I'm confused. What do compact blocks have to do with this?

Before v0.17, Bitcoin Core nodes would simply not connect to pruned nodes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@wtogami @orionwl I believe they always relayed both blocks and transactions. What was missing was a way to advertise that they did that without also (falsely) advertising that they serve the whole historical chain.

BIP159 changed that. It is advertised as of Bitcoin Core 0.16, and used in 0.17+.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Ethan_Heilman In C, a[b] is syntactic sugar for *(a+b), as arrays aren't first-class data types (they can be declared for allocation purposes, but for anything but sizeof, they decay into a pointer).

In C++, C-style arrays have the same behavior, but e.g. std::vector's [] takes unsigned arg.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
For power-of-2 orders XOR can be used directly. The smallest other example is order 6, with for example this Cayley table:

(0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
(1, 0, 3, 2, 5, 4)
(2, 4, 0, 5, 1, 3)
(3, 5, 4, 0, 2, 1)
(4, 3, 5, 1, 0, 2)
(5, 2, 1, 4, 3, 0)

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: This is more a theoretical question than a practical one; I have an approach that works and is very efficient, but has a very slight non-uniformity.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
I believe these exist for every even order (I've found ones for orders 2,4,6,8,10,12 using brute force), but I'm wondering of larger ones (order <= 2^30) exists that can be efficiently evaluated.

Doing so would enable an elegant way to generalize Cuckoo filters to non-2^n size.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cryptodavidw @arikaleph @JeremyRubin If I remember correctly, GPU mining software would perform around 122 SHA256 rounds (where 192 would be expected for a naive implementation).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cryptodavidw @arikaleph @JeremyRubin Double SHA256, as implemented by miners, is not just invoking a generic SHA256 twice. It's highly specialized for 80-byte inputs, and optimized for throughput, not latency. Part of the computation can be skipped because all you care about is the high N bits.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @benediktbuenz Exactly how expected? Following https://t.co/K4vWHqkQ37 the distribution of the lowest of N hashes (normalized to 0..1) should have CDF F(h) = 1-(1-h)^N, which for small h can be approximated as 1-exp(-hN). with hN=2^(92-91.31), there is a 19.99% chance of seeing such high min h.

I think BIP113 was the right thing to do, but it has nothing to do with the consensus algorithm (difficulty, most-work chain, ... or any of those). It only affects transaction validity within a chain.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @zawy3 @hrdng @kallerosenbaum @xer0c @renepickhardt The blocks are the order.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hrdng @kallerosenbaum @xer0c @renepickhardt Good point, you're right. It does prevent issues for miners whose local clock is not monotonous, or who are using nTime grinding to add bits, though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @hrdng @kallerosenbaum @xer0c @renepickhardt I don't remember if it was a consideration or not, but it was certainly a necessity for BIP68. Otherwise it wouldn't be possible to determine exactly whether or not a transaction is legal in the next block, requiring ugly mempool logic to reevaluate repeatedly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@xer0c @renepickhardt Yes, there is.

Every block has a metric called the MedianTimePast, which is the median of the timestamps of the 11 blocks preceding it. Every block's timestamp must be strictly larger than its MTP. In aggregate this means the MTPs form a monotonically increasing sequence.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt This was a guess.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @renepickhardt Difference between timestamps in all pairs of successive blocks in the main chain.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @murchandamus @MF_HODL That's for R grinding. It's very similar for s grinding, but using an algebraic trick (s can just be negated without invalidating the signature) the first bit does not even require grinding. Beyond that it's also a factor 256 per gained byte.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@murchandamus @MF_HODL Yeah. It follows from the signed-integer encoding in DER. A zero padding bit must be present to indicate the number is positive, which means that >= 2^255 another byte is needed (33 in total). Between 2^255 and 2^247 it is 32 bytes; etc.

Every extra byte is 256x more work.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @murchandamus @MF_HODL You could iterate on average 2^9 times to save another byte, or 2^17 for yet another, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Jacksper13 It takes some time to construct a new block candidate based on mempool + previous confirmed blocks, and distribute that information to all hashers.

When a pool detects a new block, they quickly tell their miners "start mining empty block on top", until a full candidate is ready.
