name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @lukechilds @MagicalBitcoin @apoelstra The alternative would be a logistical nightmare. All mempool transactions would need to be reevaluated every block. Reasoning about validity of unconfirmed transactions would be a pain (e.g. what if you're paid using a tx spending the output of a soon-to-be expired tx?)

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @lukechilds @MagicalBitcoin @apoelstra However, it would likely be pointless. The nSequence and nLocktime fields themselves do observe time, and can only express larger-than constraints. Bitcoin transaction validity should be monotonic: once valid, absent double-spend, they remain valid.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @lukechilds @MagicalBitcoin @apoelstra I take back what I said. CSV and CLTV don't actually observe the time; the observe tblhe nLocktime/nSequence field in the transaction. There wouldn't be any problems with having an ability in Script to make arbitrary (including less than, negation, ...) statements about them.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MagicalBitcoin @lukechilds @apoelstra For example miniscript "l:older(N)" translates to "IF 0 ELSE <N> CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY". This is dissatisfiable (a valid script can contain this, while the condition older is not true), but it being dissatisfied does not prove the condition is false. Just that it wasn't proven.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MagicalBitcoin @lukechilds @apoelstra Similarly, "not(older(N))" would not mean "younger(N)" - there (intentionally) does not exist a way in script to express a younger-than condition (because it would mean a tx that invalidates itself). "not(older(N))" would just be "do not prove time is past N", also trivial.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MagicalBitcoin @lukechilds @apoelstra Conceptually it doesn't make sense, because script conditions are monotonic. What would and(pk(A),not(pk(B))) mean? "B does not sign" is trivially satisfied; B would just never bother signing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @publicharvest_ Yes and no. All potentially-spendable subsidies together is indeed slightly less than 21M, but obviously the real supply was going to be far smaller than that anyway. The most obvious reason is lost coins/keys, but there is more: https://t.co/MTRI3IKrv0

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @etimarcus Yeah, we should have rounded the answers to 3 digits and asked for the closest match.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Of course, coinbase outputs are only spendable after 100 blocks. So in order to be potentially-spendable (as stated in the question), we can only count the subsidies up to block 5101440).

This will require a consensus change to address, which I expect will be widely accepted.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
(d) adds something very obscure (and to be honest, if it wasn't for Russell's suggestion I would have answered (c) myself).

The block timestamp is a 32-bit integer. Under the stated assumptions, after 5101541 blocks, that timestamp will overflow and no more blocks can be mined.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: (c) Also takes into account that the 50 BTC created by the genesis block is unspendable. This may have been an oversight, or intentional, but whatever the reason, the original code did not enter the genesis coinbase into its index. In the current code, it's an explicit exception.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
(b) Takes into account that the per-block subsidy is expressed in (and rounded down to) satoshis. After 10 halvenings, the subsidy would be 0.048828125 BTC, which gets rounded to 0.04882812 BTC per block.

That's not all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
(a) is the often-stated total supply of BTC. It's what you get if you assume an infinity of blocks, with per-block subsidy halving from 50 BTC every 210000 blocks.

That's not correct.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
This was a trick question (of course...), but given the stated assumptions, the total sum of all subsidies is... (d) 20999948.91679418 BTC.

I'm happily surprised it's the most-voted answer, but wonder if people maybe voted for most significant digits?

Explanation follows.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@r0ckstardev @CoinCornerDanny Yeah, the original code was simply invalid C++. Shifting an integers by more than its width is undefined behavior, and compilers are allowed to assume it never happens.

In practice, most platforms shift by (val % width), so e.g. a 67-bit shift turns into a 3-bit shift.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @phil_geiger @ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi No, but it will also not allow the amount in circulation to be more than 47.32 million, or more than 20.9999499769 million. What makes 21 million special?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @phil_geiger @ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi Before someone corrects me that the Bitcoin Core source code actually contains "MAX_MONEY = 21000000 * COIN": you'd be right, but that constant has nothing to do with the supply schedule. It's a limit on the maximum amount in one UTXO.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@phil_geiger @ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi Certainly some limit exists, but why do you say 21 million? That number does not appear anywhere in the source code, and it isn't the maximum possible amount implied by it (which is 20999949.9769 BTC).

That leads me to conclude 21 million is nothing more than an approximation.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi The first can be any number above 20999949.9769 BTC. The second is exactly 20999949.9769 BTC. The third is unknown (nobody knows how many coins are actually burned).

So I guess the only actual meaningful number is 20999949.9769 BTC, if you need one.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi I think there are 3 consistent definitions:
* Some limit that fits the "they always existed" abstraction.
* The amount that could have been brought into circulation if nobody ever burned any after genesis.
* The max amount that can ever be in circular in the future.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ecurrencyhodler @murchandamus @amizi So I don't think that's a particularly elucidating definition. It's more useful to define supply as the amount that can be brought into circulation, which is 20999949.9769 BTC - minus whatever was burned afterwards.

Also: MM to mean million makes no sense. M = mega.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @fiatjaf @SomsenRuben @ercwl If your goal is making things like setup-less multisig work (I know your pubkey, so I can involve you in a 2-of-2 multisig with me without talking to you): I don't think that works anyway, as you'd need to talk to them to get the public key in the first place.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@fiatjaf @SomsenRuben @ercwl You mean raw scripts in sPK? I think that was a bad idea since P2SH was known:
* bloat UTXO set
* reveals receiver policy to sender
* receiver needs to scan every output
* sender needs to know exactly what script "tricks" the receiver supports.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @fiatjaf @ercwl So a P2WPK wouldn't have been able to encompass every script condition (solved now with Taproot), and doing it just for single-participant outputs isn't something we considered. Segwit was already a big change, and intentionally avoided changing a lot more.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @SomsenRuben @fiatjaf @ercwl At the time segwit was proposed, my opinion was that ideally everything would be some 32-byte scripthash scheme like P2WSH, as that was the most fungible output type we knew of at the time. P2WPKH was cheaper, but only usable for single-participant constructions.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ercwl @weekndinvegas I'll let you know if I come up with something.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ercwl @Xatarrer Exactly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@benediktbuenz @simulx @ercwl All old schemes remain valid (so you can keep using P2PK(H)/multisig/whatever, in P2SH/P2WSH or not).

Taproot can't be used inside P2SH. Reasons include security (80-bit collision against P2SH), and loss of fungibility (your choice of P2SH or not reveals things).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@jmcorgan @theinstagibbs @ercwl @adam3us Also, everything in the Bitcoin protocol is little endian (and ECDSA keys/signature and SHA256 are seen as opaque byte arrays... which are sometimes interpreted as 256-bit LE numbers which are then shown in BE in RPC because how we write numbers...).

</stockholm_syndrome>

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ChristopherA If you tell me how many errors you want to correct up to what length, I can just construct a BCH code for that (it's just some algebra). It won't be as close to optimal as we got with Bech32, but it'll have the desired properties.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ChristopherA The CPU time we spent for Bech32 was basically to get somewhat better error detection properties, but at the cost of a search proportional to the search space. For longer codes this quickly becomes infeasible, but it's probably also unnecessary.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ChristopherA Yes, that's described in section "Selected properties" in BIP173.

For a new code, it really depends on what properties you want? Do you care about (efficient) error correction? Detection properties? What length?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ChristopherA Length here is expressed in 5-bit symbols (including checksum characters) to be clear, not bytes of data.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ChristopherA Bech32 is designed for error detection, not correction (though it can be used for that).

Len <= 8: detect 6
Len <= 18: detect 5
Len <= 89: detect 4
Len <= 1023: detect 3
Len <= inf: detect 1

(Detecting N) can always be traded in for ((correcting i) and (detecting N-2i)).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @LukeDashjr @pqai3 @KLoaec @meeDamian There is a curious property that Taproot has w.r.t. QC: an attacker can't tell if an output is intended to have a key path or not. If they find the corresponding private key and spend using the key path, it results in a transferable proof that ECDLP is broken.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @LukeDashjr @pqai3 @KLoaec @meeDamian But I don't expect this will be necessary - at some point quantum-safe locking scripts will be introduced. And then, maybe decades later or never, if QC worry becomes real, nobody is using ECC-based coins anymore.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @LukeDashjr @pqai3 @KLoaec @meeDamian That's theoretically possible for some coins (e.g. PQC zero knowledge proof that shows you know how the private key was derived from a BIP32 hardened path or seed), but it'd take 10s of kB per transaction at least, which is not really feasible.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @pqai3 @KLoaec @meeDamian Eh, no. If a QC can ever spend lost ECC-locked coins, I believe it's game over for Bitcoin. How can an asset maintain value if an attacker has the ability to flood the market with the significant portion of the entire supply?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @meeDamian * Lastly, as the market and technology matures, I suspect that the fraction of coins truly lost (not just unmoved) will tend to zero. So apart from a one-time large airdrop of new minable coins far in the future, it probably doesn't accomplish much.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @meeDamian * If long-term incentives for mining are the goal, I believe a different inflation schedule is strictly better than gameable approaches like this. Again: this is all in an alternate universe where Bitcoin hasn't been created yet - and maybe it would never have taken off if so.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @meeDamian * Depending on timeframes, if it's very long (like 200y) you get problems like it being ineffective for generations, and then causes a market flood far in the future. If it's short it may have milder effects, but creates a perverse incentive for miners to delay rotations.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @meeDamian * Even if this were in an alternative universe where Bitcoin can be created a different way, it has issues, such as complicating very long-term storage - which I suspect is a goal of many current hodlers.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 15/15 I hope this was interesting, and you can now go back to your regularly scheduled COVID-19 news (but please stay inside).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 14/15 Finally, it also explains why the C code didn't result in a uniform result: zooming in by a factor two in every step interacts with the way floating point numbers are represented as binary mantissas. Eventually the rounding errors accumulated will interact with the result.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 13/15 The function we started with (f(x)=4*x*(1-x)) is called the logistic map, and it is mentioned in its Wikipedia article that it is a transformed version ("topological conjugate") of the tent map f2. We've derived this, and it means that since f2(x) is chaotic, so is f(x).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 12/15 That means, regardless of what the input is, if it has an infinity of bits (or decimals) that are uniformly distributed after some initial prefix, every step just makes us explore more and more of those. That is obviously going to reach all ranges equally.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 11/15 Turns out, it's correct. And it's known as the tent map (https://t.co/ZRVz8bLQ3R), and it's even easy to see why it is chaotic. It's either doubling x, or doubling (1-x), effectively "zooming in" by a factor 2 in every step.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 10/15 Finally, I looked at a plot of 2/pi*arcsin(sin(pi*x)): https://t.co/LB1TrTGtH4. Wait, just a piecewise linear function? It's indeed 2*x for x=0..1/2, but 2-2*x for x=1/2..1.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 9/15 Looking at that expression, 2/pi*arcsin(sqrt(sin^2(pi*x))): it has a sqrt of a square of a positive number (with x=0..1 at least), meaning it can be simplified to just 2/pi*arcsin(sin(pi*x)). Thinking that arcsin(sin(x))=x, this would just be 2*x. That cannot be!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 8/14 I tried instead just iterating f(x)=4*x*(1-x), and then determining the distribution of t() applied to the results. Turns out that is much more uniform, so the difference between the two must have to do with rounding.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 7/14 Excited for such a nice simplification (narrator: hahaha, he'll see), I wrote a small C program to perform this iteration a billion times... and it seems the result is not uniform at all. What did I do wrong?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Putting that all together means f2(x) = t(f(t^-1(x)) = 2/pi*arcsin(sqrt(4*sin^2(pi/2*x)*(1-sin^2(pi/2*x)))). Again, Wolfram Alpha helps me simplify that to 2/pi*arcsin(sqrt(sin^2(pi*x))).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: The CDF is Beta(x;1/2,1/2)/Beta(1/2,1/2). Wolfram Alpha helpfully tells me that's equal to 2/pi*arcsin(sqrt(x)), which is our t(x). t^-1(x) is its inverse, sin^2(pi/2*x).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 4/14 Perhaps writing that out will teach me something about why it is chaotic? We need to find t(x): a function that uniformizes the Beta(1/2,1/2) distribution. That's just its CDF: if you feed g-distributed numbers to the CDF of g itself, you get uniform output in [0,1].

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 3/14 If that's the case, it should be possible to transform that function to one operating on a uniform distribution (between 0 and 1): if t(x) transforms Beta-distributed numbers to uniform ones, then f2(x) = t(f(t^-1(x))) should be chaotic on uniform numbers.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 2/14 A few days ago I saw this tweet by @ProbFact: https://t.co/fjizF4tARr. It claims that iterating f(x) = 4*x*(1-x) will give chaotic results (tiny differences in the input will result in wildly different results) that are Beta(1/2,1/2)-distributed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: 1/14 Here is a thread about something I learned about chaotic functions (something I basically knew nothing about). It's all on Wikipedia, I learned later, but describing how I found out may be interesting.

tweet: @jb55 I disagree it's that clear cut. Merging favors avoiding invalidation of review. Rebasing favors auditability of history, which does not care about what history the code had before it reached acceptable shape.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @adam3us If the infection of individual samples are identically and independently distributed, with probably of infection p each, then the "top level" tests should be for mixes of approximately log(1/2)/log(1-p) samples. Once you find an infected mix, use binary subdivision.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @adam3us Assuming you can arbitrarily mix samples and get an 100% accurate "any of the constituent samples is infected" from testing the mix, you get maximum information (and minimal tests) by constructing mixes that have a-priori probability 50% of combined infection.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @_drgo @adam3us I think it's common practice to combine multiple samples and test them simultaneously, and then subdivide as needed (perhaps not in the context of COVID-19, but I have heard about this before). I don't see what Merkle trees have to do with it, though.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kixunil The padding in SHA2 literally writes the 64-bit integer to the end of the stream with the number of bits before it. If there were more than 2^64-1 bits written, that integer would overflow, and presumably some security proofs would break.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kixunil In fact, I suspect nearly every SHA256 lacks this message length check.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @kixunil And it's of course possible to have an incorrect implementation of SHA256 that does not check whether the message is within the size limit, but even that is irrelevant: it would take decades of (sequential) CPU time to reach the limit.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@kixunil I don't know what that means.

The scheme specifies when the function gets invoked, you have no choice in this matter. There is nothing wrong with invoking it more, it's just impossible to do without trying to hash an oversized message.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @archy_harrison In practice, they're right. The limit is so high that for almost all practical purposes it can be treated as unlimited.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Toprolling Nope.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Signalyze01 Exactly.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @NicolasDorier SHA256 processing the input in blocks of 64 bytes, but its input is in fact limited to ~2.3 exabytes (2^61-1 bytes).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
That would suggest 2^64 / 512 = 2^55 compression functions. However, the input is padded with at least 65 bits + whatever needed to fill another 512-bit block. 

Therefore the answer is: at most 2^55 + 1 invocations.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The correct answer was (a) 36028797018963969.

SHA256 is hash function from the set of variable-length bit strings to 256 bit outputs. The input can be at most 2^64 - 1 bits long. The compression function is invoked once per 512 bit block.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: To be clear: this is just curiosity, I have no interest in any non-standard encryption scheme. But the fact that a competition for AES was held after SHA-2 existed, and is presumably based on a block cipher, makes me wonder what the reason for that could be.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
Dear crypto(graphy)twitter,

SHA-2 uses a Davies-Meyer compression function based on an underlying block cipher. Is that block cipher interesting? Are there any reasons why you'd not want to use it as the basis for an encryption scheme?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MIT1991_2 Slightly easier:

3^n + 15^n = 0 mod 13
<=> 3^n*(1 + 5^n) = 0 mod 13
<=> 5^n = -1 mod 13
<=> 5^n = 5^2 mod 13
<=> n = 2 mod 4 [5 has order 4 in Z13,*]

True for n=2^64 + 2.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MIT1991_2 I'll bite.

3^n + 15^n = 0 mod 13?
<=> 3^n = -(2^n) = 0 mod 13
<=> (2^4)^n = (2^6)*(2^n) = 0 mod 13
<=> 2^(4*n) = 2^(n+6) = 0 mod 13
<=> 4*n = n+6 mod 12 [2 is generator of Z13,*; order 12]
<=> n = 2 mod 4

True for n = 2^64 + 2.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@2357_is_prime @cpc464_a500 @adam3us @peterktodd @aantonop @alexbosworth @udiWertheimer @WhalePanda @AaronvanW @Excellion @starkness @roasbeef @rusty_twit @saleemrash1d @BitMEXResearch @kyletorpey The problem is that if at some point 9 subsequent block intervals happen within 32 minutes, the next block after that has an elevated chance of causing another 9-in-32min event.

So you can't say that each of the 144 blocks in a day have an independent 0.57% chance.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cpc464_a500 @adam3us @peterktodd @aantonop @alexbosworth @udiWertheimer @WhalePanda @AaronvanW @Excellion @starkness @roasbeef @rusty_twit @saleemrash1d @BitMEXResearch @kyletorpey Assuming constant hashrate, and difficulty always exactly matching that hashrate, as well as perfectly accurate timestamps in every block (all three incorrect assumptions...), a simulation shows this should happen around once per 568 blocks, or every 4 days.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @FractalEncrypt @cpc464_a500 @adam3us @peterktodd @aantonop @alexbosworth @udiWertheimer @WhalePanda @AaronvanW @Excellion @starkness @roasbeef @rusty_twit @saleemrash1d @BitMEXResearch @kyletorpey Every block has 0.57% chance, 1/0.57% = once every 175 blocks.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @cpc464_a500 @adam3us @peterktodd @aantonop @alexbosworth @udiWertheimer @WhalePanda @AaronvanW @Excellion @starkness @roasbeef @rusty_twit @saleemrash1d @BitMEXResearch @kyletorpey That's not taking into account the fact that the duration of windows of 9 interblock intervals are not independent. I may be off by up to a factor 9 here.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@cpc464_a500 @adam3us @peterktodd @aantonop @alexbosworth @udiWertheimer @WhalePanda @AaronvanW @Excellion @starkness @roasbeef @rusty_twit @saleemrash1d @BitMEXResearch @kyletorpey That's 9 block intervals during a period of time where 3.2 are expected.

Type in Wolfram Alpha: "P(n>=9) where n~Poisson(3.2)", and you get 0.57%, meaning something this extreme should happen every 100/0.57 = 175 blocks = 1.5 days.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @bio_location @BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman There are so many ways that implementations can screw up in non-obvious ways.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman I think it depends - state that needs to be kept secret and untamperable, is very scary to me. It'll of course be a necessity for some protocols, and we need good solutions for those. But at the same time, I think we should keep researching what is possible without...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman And we're working on a solution for the latter too (stateless MuSig signing), but it has some fairly unrealistic trade-offs.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman This is the reason why I focused initially just Taproot/Schnorr: they keep working fine if all you have a single secret seed, and no secure long-term storage beyond that. For signing you need only short-term session state to be secure.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman If you have a paper wallet, where do you store the key material you get from the interactive setup?

Write them all down for every setup you participate in?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@BobMcElrath @paddypisa @Ethan_Heilman Signing, not setup. You can compute MuSig addresses using just the participants' xpubs or so.

All Schnorr multisignature schemes have interactive signing. But MuSig/Taproot have noninteractive setup. Thresholds, multiparty ECDSA, Graftroot, ... have interactive setup too.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball I guess I'm guilty of that too, as I included MuSig (and multiparty/threshold sigs in general) under Schnorr. I think of them as one thing, as no consensus-level features are needed beyond Schnorr signatures to enable them, but you're right that they really  are protocols on top.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball Yes, that's fair - and a minor annoyance of mine too how easily many things get conflated. But I also think this is inevitable - people need an approximation to talk about when they don't care about the technical details.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @BobMcElrath @Ethan_Heilman Multiparty ECDSA could in theory achieve the same. But in practice that seems unreasonable, as it always needs an interactive setup (to the best of my knowledge). So you'd need to get participating cold storage keys out of their vault to even compute an address to send to.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @BobMcElrath @Ethan_Heilman The assumption underlying Taproot is that a large majority of spending policies could be written as "(some set of keys) OR (complex rules)". Schnorr makes it practical to actually use that left branch efficiently, creating a Shelling point for ideal spends.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball If your point is that even this isn't Schnorr itself even, but adoption of e.g. MuSig and Taproot or a variety of other protocols by wallet software, you're right - but that's true for almost anything. Things that aren't adopted don't help, and the best we can do is incentives.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball Still, I think it's unfair to say Schnorr does not improve privacy. Just because it doesn't address the most frequently talked about privacy leak (tx linkage) doesn't mean it does nothing at all.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball Of course, cross-input aggregation is separate from Schnorr signatures (and it seems many people think they're the same - partially my fault because early Schnorr work was motivated by that).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@paddypisa @adam3us @moneyball I think you're confusing things.

Transaction linkage privacy (1) and spending policy privacy (2) are distinct problems to solve.

Schnorr: (1) nothing (2) a bit

Taproot: (1) nothing (2) a lot

Cross-input aggregation: (1) indirectly by incentivizing CJ (2) nothing

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa On the other hand, it's possible to drop script (or any kind of advanced spending conditions) entirely, making policy privacy trivially solved - but only by moving what it would reveal elsewhere. Again, not something that's likely appealing to the ecosystem for adoption.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa Alternatives include much more cutting edge ZK techniques that hide the script/policy entirely - but it seems those come with costs and assumptions that would make them much harder to be adopted, especially if it would mean a general ZK proof even for simple payments.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @CryptoBabel @paddypisa That said, I think things like that are inevitable when technical terms end up being adopted by groups that aren't particularly interested in the technical details.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @CryptoBabel @paddypisa For better or worse, the term "Schnorr" has become a term that encompasses a whole bunch of technologies and ideas. Its advantages are often overstated, and the name is an approximation (most benefits don't actually come from Schnorr signatures themselves).

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @hdevalence @paddypisa But in such a way that if they cooperate, the transaction is indistinguishable from a normal (simple single key) payment (so even the fact that a script existed in the first place remains hidden).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ecurrencyhodler @paddypisa Well, but Taproot is, and Schnorr is a necessary piece in the puzzle to make it effective.

Even the combination is limited to just "spending policy privacy", and only in optimistic cases - but it comes with no security assumptions or validation cost increases.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@paddypisa I think the combination of Schnorr and Taproot is a major improvement. It keeps script functionality, but enables/incentivizes hiding it in cooperative cases.

Like everything, it's a trade-off of course. Finding a balance between cost/incentives to adopt and privacy is hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @paddypisa Now, I do agree that Schnorr signatures themselves are nearly useless as a privacy improvement. But I also don't think that's what people care about, or mean when just saying "Schnorr".

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@paddypisa Well, of course not. It's a tool that can be used for a number of things, and some of them improve privacy.

But then again, I don't think anything is a privacy *solution*. Even a perfectly ZK mechanism with all transactions indistinguishable may leak information through P2P, ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MadarsV I can make a slightly stronger claim: for p(x) with const term 1, x^n + 1 mod p(x) = 0 holds for n < 2^(deg(p)-1) (so there is always a solution with m=0 in the earlier formulation).

That seems harder to prove.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV Aha: if this holds for p(x) with const term 1, it holds for all p(x). In this restricted case, if n >= deg(p), x^n mod p(x) will have const term 1 as well. This means the domain for those is just 2^(deg(p)-1) possible values.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV Ah, that makes sense. However, your typo seems to be close to reality, as I don't see any n values above 2^(deg(p)-1)-1.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV Actually, where does the deg(p)-1 come from? ([anything] mod p(x)) has 2^(deg(p)) possible outcomes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV For example, x^15 + x^5 + x^3 + 1 divides x^16383 + 1.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV You can simplify the problem to "Is every GF(2) polynomial p(x) with constant term 1 a divisor of (x^n + 1) for some integer n?". When just considering those, n = 2^(deg(p)-1)-1 is reached in some examples.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @MadarsV Ha, nice!

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Ravi_21M Sure, x^(fieldsize) - x has every field element as root.

I don't see how that's useful, though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
The resulting values of n do seem to grow quickly with the degree of the polynomial, though.

For example, x^8 + x^6 + x^4 + x + 1 divides x^217 + 1.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
It seems that every nonzero polynomial over GF(2) can be written as a divisor of either x^n or of x^n + x^m, for some integers m and n.

Is there an obvious proof for this?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Cash2BTC Segwit transactions are added to the UTXO set just like every other transaction.

Witness data however never enters the UTXO set (neither for legacy transactions or segwit ones). That's why segwit gives it a discount.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: Normally not a discussion I'd choose to have again, but I think this is a nice analogy.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @ggmesh @bramcohen @Blockstream @MyLegacyKit @el33th4xor @VitalikButerin @ChicoCrypto @HamEggsnSam @adam3us @NickSzabo4 With segwit you get the option of not paying (as much) for your witness data (small luggage). Of course, you have to actually bring it into the cabin (choosing segwit) to get the discount. If you check your carry-on approved luggage (scriptSig), you still pay full price.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ggmesh @bramcohen @Blockstream @MyLegacyKit @el33th4xor @VitalikButerin @ChicoCrypto @HamEggsnSam @adam3us @NickSzabo4 Segwit transactions and pre-segwit transactions that do the same thing are approximately the same size (sometimes slightly less, sometimes slightly more).

Segwit discounting rectifies the fact that bytes are not the only metric for measuring network impact.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@ggmesh @bramcohen @Blockstream @MyLegacyKit @el33th4xor @VitalikButerin @ChicoCrypto @HamEggsnSam @adam3us @NickSzabo4 The rationale is that witness data can be discounted, because it has far lower long-term costs to the network (it does not enter the UTXO set, in particular).

It's not arbitrarily charging luggage differently; it's charging differently for checked and carry-on luggage.

tweet:
@ecurrencyhodler Schnorr multisignatures always have interactive signing.

Whether it's also interactive at setup time depends. MuSig (n-of-n only) is not; native k-of-n threshold signatures (with k<n) always are.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TomerStrolight @TusharJain_ It turns out that it interacts in complex ways with other important changes.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tdryja @TusharJain_ The BIP recommends using H+r*G, with H a well-known second generator (with no known DL w.r.t. G), and r and a random value. Revealing r is enough to prove DL was broken (or at least DL of H is known).

Please don't stop bugging me.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tdryja @TusharJain_ Oh if you're talking about unlikely-to-matter brushes with QC, I think there is another neat one:

With Taproot, outputs without known DL will be created, which are still spendable (through script). If a DLP breaker steals such coins, you have transferable proof DL is broken.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tdryja @TusharJain_ What? Taproot is in no way PQC.

And Taproot restricted to single-participant internal keys is no better than just pubkeyhash/scripthash, so I think the "technically works" doesn't really matter.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @tdryja @TusharJain_ The assumption underlying Taproot is that effectively any spending policy can be extended with "OR single key checksig", which can be used in practice. Without the ability to represent agreement of multiple parties as a single key, that assumption does not hold.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@tdryja @TusharJain_ Technically that works, but I don't think it's useful without key aggregation, as you could only have a single-key key path, rather than an everyone-agrees or so.

Multiparty ECDSA of course exists, but it's painful at best, and IIRC its interactive keygen would be incompatible.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@JGMontoyaS @TusharJain_ Lots of things!

* Various improvements to P2P, especially Erlay
* Making more advanced Bitcoin scripts more usable (through things like output descriptors, Miniscript, PSBT, ...)
* Research into stateless Schnorr multisig signing (paper coming soon)
* ...

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @JGMontoyaS @TusharJain_ We'll certainly learn a lot from how Schnorr is used.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@JGMontoyaS @TusharJain_ There is no entity that can set global priorities for everyone.

Bitcoin and research into improvements consist of people through, and people have their own focus. I can't speak for anyone else, but I myself am not working on cross-input agg, though I have some ideas.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ @wasabiwallet But Schnorr signatures itself do not benefit CoinJoin, or at least not more than they benefit everything else.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@TusharJain_ @wasabiwallet Cross-input aggregation has turned to be pretty complex to specify correctly, as it interacts in weird ways with other ways to extend Script.

This is just engineering, not fundamentally difficult.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ That effort is now published as BIP340/341/342. I hope it finds its way into Bitcoin at some point, and future efforts can bring things like cross-input aggregation in future updates.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ About 1.5 years ago a few people including me started working on a concrete "minimal" proposal that just focuses on Taproot, and everything needed to make it effective (in particular, Schnorr signatures). To avoid complexity, it avoided cross-input aggregation and other things.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@TusharJain_ Soon it became clear that there could be an ever-growing set of technologies that all are improvements to Bitcoin's script system, and which actually work better when combined.

Unfortunately, it would also grow increasing complex to specify, implement, and convince everyone of.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ Taproot clearly benefits a large number of applications, and requires Schnorr signatures. To me, it quickly got merged into the effort that included Schnorr and cross-input aggregation. Not much later Graftroot was invented, and that too got thrown into the bag.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ Along the way, something else was invented: Taproot. In short, it's a way to hide scripts in transactions. In many cases it means you cannot distinguish a payment from a Lightning channel opening from an atomic swap anymore.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@TusharJain_ So originally we were looking into using Schnorr signatures as a building block for implementing cross-input aggregation. That would enable having effectively just one signature per transaction, regardless of its number of inputs.

This would be very desirable.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ Schnorr signatures on themselves are a fairly boring improvement over ECDSA; they enable some simpler/cheaper multisig, adaptor signatures to avoid hashes in atomic swaps, better sedurity proof... but nothing that would actually benefit average transactions.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ I'm partially to blame for this confusion, as our original reason for starting research into Schnorr signatures was to enable cross-input aggregation.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @TusharJain_ This is an often repeated advantage, but it requires cross-input signature aggregation, which is not included in these proposals.

tweet: Thanks to everyone who helped us get here: co-authors @ajtowns, @n1ckler, and @real_or_random, everyone who contributed to the document, the participants in the @bitcoinoptech workshops and structured review, Greg Maxwell for the original idea, and many others.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: That means that these documents are our final proposal for integrating Schnorr and Taproot into Bitcoin. Whether it gets accepted by the ecosystem, and how, is up to you.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: However in this case I believe we (the authors) waited to request numbers until the proposal and writeups were fairly mature. Barring significant issues found in review (which remains welcome of course), I do not think we intend to make semantical changes anymore.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@KLoaec In the current compiler, if the input policy has the same subexpression twice, the resulting compilation to Miniscript will have it twice as well.

There could be some policy-to-policy optimizations to improve upon that, but if no policy exists that avoids it, it's inevitable.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @KLoaec That said, would thres(4,A,B,C,D,after(6),after(6)) work? It has still some duplication, but it's just the timelocks rather than the keys.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @KLoaec I don't think what you're asking for directly is possible... ultimately Miniscript is a collection of composable patterns, and not every trick possible in Script will translate. In particular, common subexpression elimination is very hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @theinstagibbs @TheBlueMatt Also as leaf versions are specific to leaves (of the Merkle tree of scripts), if an output can be spent using multiple disjunct conditions, and those are encoded as separate scripts in the tree, it means you don't reveal that new opcode is used unless that path is actually taken.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @TheBlueMatt @theinstagibbs Not without introducing a new witness to the P2P protocol and all that entails.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @theinstagibbs @TheBlueMatt You could, but that seems like a waste of version space. It's also pretty terrible for policy privacy as you'd be revealing on every payment that this is a transaction that involves the new opcode.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @TheBlueMatt @theinstagibbs That's obviously my own thinking, and contingent on taproot (or something fairly similar) eventually activating on the network.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@Ethan_Heilman @TheBlueMatt @theinstagibbs So:
* Witness version: structure of commitment to policy
* Taproot leaf version: significant changes to script itself
* OP_SUCCESSx (or OP_NOPx where possible): new opcodes

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @Ethan_Heilman @TheBlueMatt Witness versions have some limitations (only 16 available values, revealed on send, ...), so it is most appropriate for changing commitment structure (see @theinstagibbs' response). Taproot introduces a new level (leaf version) that is per script and only revealed on spend.

tweet:

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@hamal03 The "everyone agrees" branch is a simplification I use in explanations, as it's easy to see an everyone-agrees is generally safe to add to any spending condition.

But there is no requirement; you can pick any pure-key combination as internal key, including a single key.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:

tweet: @MrHodl @girevik_ Another unpopular opinion: if you must rely on manual coin selection by end users, you have no hope for privacy. Even if you yourself religiously apply caution about what to mix, it is unreasonable to expect that those who you transact with will do the same.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @MangoFarmAssets @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP @commerceblock Yes, absolutely. My point is only that this is not easy to accomodate for all use cases, and for those, resistance to non-selective censorship matters.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @MangoFarmAssets @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP @commerceblock They make it possible to detect and prove a certain kind of functionary misbehavior.

They don't prevent it.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @MangoFarmAssets @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP @commerceblock Imagine the old smart property use case, where you have a car that has an associated Liquid token to represent ownership. You can present it with transaction + proof of inclusion to change the key that can operate it. This may be useful, but makes firing the signers hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @MangoFarmAssets @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP @commerceblock Liquid blocks themselves are a proof of inclusion. I was just talking about the Liquid chain, not about timestamping into Bitcoin.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @MangoFarmAssets @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP At a time-scale of weeks, sure, which is fine for consensus rule changes in Bitcoin. But failure modes of malfunctioning/confiscated functionaries can be much faster.

Also say HSMs for Liquid-linked products may want block inclusion proofs, and changing those keys may be hard.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP Non-selective censorship is still censorship, and is a risk in certain scenarios (and likely the reason why e-cash never took off despite amazing privacy).

I can imagine it's not much of a concern for the type of issued assets imagined for Liquid, but maybe it is for some.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @wtogami @shesek @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP Yes, agreed - better privacy makes it harder to selectively censor (as opposed to censor outright). But it's hard to quantify how much this adds.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @wtogami @shesek @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP Correction: 2/3 is necessary to accept a transaction, so 1/3+1 is enough to censor.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@shesek @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP That's a different (and IMO more interesting) use case. I like it because it's close to the best security model possible when talking about issued assets that correspond to some real-world thing backing it, as you're inherently trusting issuer.

Even less relevant to BTC though.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@wtogami @shesek @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP "Censorship is hard to pull off without 2/3 majority".

Yes, exactly, so you're trusting a 2/3 majority not to censor. I fully agree it is likely very hard to pull off, but it *is* a trust assumption, which won't be acceptable to everyone.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP Sure. But would you say that Coinbase deploying a new feature is exciting news for Bitcoin? Something to put on the same scale as a protocol improvement?

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @shesek @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP Yes, in general. For example I think we may learn a thing or two from having Taproot activate on Liquid. But at the same time maybe not, because people will need to implement wallet software to make use of it, and that may not happen long until it's active on mainnet.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP In any case, I don't think any particular feature we're working on for Liquid will have that much of an appeal that these concerns are relevant.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP You're also bringing up Liquid taking off load from the mainchain.

I think that's a double edged sword. For users who already trust the federation, that's great - those tx have no need to be on-chain anyway. But if it ends up drawing others, that's arguably a bad thing.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP You're certainly right that as a testbed Liquid is useful, but so many other pieces of infrastructure. For simple changes testnet is more appropriate due to smaller diff, and hopefully signet will be even better as a public testbed.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @adam3us @fluffypony @Blockstream @Excellion @Tether_to @JpCointelegraph @RSKsmart @CounterpartyXCP The comment @fluffypony was responding to is that deployment of a feature on Liquid would be big news to Bitcoin. I don't think it is. It benefits Liquid users - people who already have a trust relation with its federation - not Bitcoin users.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @dstadulis @MrHodl It's not serious advice because unless your coin is potentially extremely biased, it's (assuming computation hardness of hash functions) much better to just roll a few more coins and hash the result.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@dstadulis @MrHodl (not serious advice)

I once created this Von Neumann extractor table for groups of 8 coin flips. For an unbiased coin it produces 4.5 bits of entropy per set of 8 tosses. However, the output remains unbiased even if the coin is biased (but you'll need more tosses per bit).

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@MarkMarkafv @stephanlivera @Pete_Winn @matt_odell @Snyke Non-fungibility threatens Bitcoin's ability to act as a currency. It's essential that every coin is treated as equal valued to any other.

But improving privacy does not imply making transparency impossible.

name: Pieter Wuille

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet:
@6102bitcoin I think it's more accurate to say that Bitcoin was probably originally designed for Pay-To-IP, and P2PKH was added as a backup for when peers were offline.

That said, version 0.1 of the software supported both.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stephanlivera @Pete_Winn @matt_odell @Snyke What it does do, is enable indistinguishable atomic swaps (both cross-chain and intra-chain). These may also obfuscate linkability, but differently (and independently) from CoinJoin.

name: Pieter Wuille
tweet: @stephanlivera @Pete_Winn @matt_odell @Snyke Indeed. Taproot improves policy privacy (being unable to distinguish simple payments from multisig, and from more complex things like channel opens), but does not directly add anything for CoinJoin.
